(b) A class B licensee must close its doors to business, must be vacated of all persons except the licensee and any on-duty paid employees or agents, and must cease to do business at or before 12:00 midnight and remain closed until 6:00 a.m. on each day of the week. (c) A class B licensee which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food, or fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, may sell, dispense, serve or deliver distilled spirits between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. (d) A class B licensee may remain open and continue to sell, dispense serve or deliver malt beverages and wine until 1:00 a.m. on New Year's Day. (Ord. No. 2009-20, § 1, 8-10-09; Ord. No. 17-5, § 3, 10-9-17) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-20, § 1, adopted Aug. 10, 2009, deleted former § 3-110, and enacted a new § 3-110 as set out herein. Former § 3-110 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1967, § 3-139, Ord. of 2-12-96(1). Sec. 3-111. - Closing times. No restaurant-lounge, restaurant-pub, tavern, lounge, private club or other establishment licensed for the on premise retail sale of alcoholic beverages, as defined in this chapter, shall remain open to the public after the hour of 1:55 a.m. (Ord. No. 2009-20, § 1, 8-10-09) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-20, § 1, adopted Aug. 10, 2009, deleted former § 3-111, and enacted a new § 3-111 as set out herein. Former § 3-111 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. of 2-12-96(2). ARTICLE VI. - MICROBREWERIES.
Sec. 3-150. - Microbrewery license authorized. No individual shall be permitted to operate a microbrewery without first obtaining a proper microbrewery license from the city in the manner provided in this chapter, and each holder of a microbrewery license shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable state statutes, including rules and regulations promulgated by the Georgia Department of Revenue. (Ord. No. 17-4, § 4, 8-4-17) Sec. 3-151. - Tastings and direct-to-consumer sales from the licensed premises. Tastings and direct-to-consumer sales from a licensed microbrewery premises shall be permitted in accordance with state law, as amended from time to time. (Ord. No. 17-4, § 4, 8-4-17) Sec. 3-152. - Hours of sale. Notwithstanding any other provision of chapter 3, the hours of operation of a licensed microbrewery shall between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:30 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and on Sunday between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (Ord. No. 17-4, § 4, 8-4-17)

div.head: Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Nuisances, Ch. 11. State Law reference— City's authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(3); livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-6.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Running at large generally. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or keeping any mules, horses, cattle, hogs, goats, chickens, ducks, geese or other domestic animals or fowl to allow or permit them to run at large within the city. Any such person who allows or permits any such domestic animal or fowl to trespass upon the premises of any person, or to injure or damage his property, shall be guilty of a violation of this section. (Code 1967, § 4-1) Sec. 4-2. - Hogs. It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep hogs within the corporate limits of the city other than hogs which have been killed or slaughtered and prepared for market. (Code 1967, § 4-2) Sec. 4-3. - Chicken houses. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, maintain or use any house, lot or place for keeping any chickens, ducks, geese, guineas or other domestic fowl within fifty (50) feet of any dwelling house located within the corporate limits of the city without the written consent of every adult person residing in such house within the fifty (50) feet. (Code 1967, § 4-3) Sec. 4-4. - Keeping of cows regulated. (a) It shall be unlawful to keep any cattle, horses, mules, donkeys, sheep or goats within the corporate limits of the city confined in any area that does not provide for each animal so kept an area equal to that of a tract of land of one (1) acre. (b) The keeping of any such animal within the corporate limits of the city confined in any area less than that prescribed herein shall for each twenty-four (24) hours constitute a separate offense, and such offense shall be deemed a nuisance and subject to abatement, as well as punishment for the person responsible. (Code 1967, § 4-4; Ord. of 6-12-95) Sec. 4-5. - Cruelty to animals. Any person who overrides, overdrives, overloads, drives when overloaded, tortures, torments, deprives of necessary sustenance, cruelly beats, mutilates or cruelly kills, or causes or procures to be overridden, overdriven, overloaded, driven when overloaded, tortured, tormented, deprived of necessary sustenance, cruelly beaten, mutilated or cruelly killed any domestic animal, either as owner or otherwise, shall on conviction be punished according to the provisions of section 1-14. (Code 1967, § 4-5) Secs. 4-6—4-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - IMPOUNDING
Sec. 4-31. - Animals at large to be impounded; sold. When any horse, mule, jack, jennet, cow, calf, hog, sheep, goat, dog or any other animal is found running at large within the corporate limits of the city, it shall be seized and impounded by the chief of police or any other police officer or the superintendent of streets of the city. When any such animal is seized and impounded as herein provided, the chief of police shall proceed forthwith to sell the same at public auction to the highest bidder for cash, within the legal hours of sale, in front of the city hall after first giving five (5) days' notice of the time and place of sale, together with a description of the animal to be sold, by posting a notice at a conspicuous place at the city hall and by publishing one (1) time in a newspaper published in the county and distributed in the city, and shall pay to the city clerk-treasurer the proceeds received from such sale, after first deducting the cost and expense incident to the seizing, impounding, feeding, keeping and selling of such animal as hereinafter provided. (Code 1967, § 4-16) Sec. 4-32. - Charges for advertising impounded animals for sale; pound fee. The city shall be entitled to and shall receive the sum of five dollars ($5.00) for advertising and selling each and every animal which may be advertised and sold or advertised for sale as provided for in the preceding section, together with the additional sum of one dollar ($1.00) for each day or fraction thereof each of such animals is kept and fed by the city pending the sale thereof as hereinabove provided. (Code 1967, § 4-17) Sec. 4-33. - Redemption of impounded animals. The owner of any animal so seized and impounded shall have the right to have the same released at any time prior to the sale thereof by paying to the city clerk-treasurer or chief of police the sum that may be due for seizing and impounding, keeping, feeding and advertising the same as herein provided. (Code 1967, § 4-18) Sec. 4-34. - Owner entitled to proceeds of sale. The owner of any animal seized, impounded and sold under this article shall have the right, within sixty (60) days after the sale thereof, to receive from the city clerk-treasurer the proceeds of such sale less the costs and expenses incident thereto, upon making proper and satisfactory proof of ownership of such animal so sold as demanded by the city clerk-treasurer. (Code 1967, § 4-19) Sec. 4-35. - Unauthorized release of animals from pound. Any person who breaks into the city pound or releases any animals impounded under the laws and ordinances of the city shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 for such offense. This section does not apply to the release of any such animals under authority of the city law by a police officer of the city. (Code 1967, § 4-20) Secs. 4-36—4-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DOGS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-56. - Vaccination and tag required. (a) All dogs within the city shall be vaccinated against rabies on or before the first day of March of each year, and each dog shall wear a tag showing that it has been so vaccinated. Dogs being brought into the city after the first day of March shall be vaccinated immediately. (b) It shall be unlawful to keep, maintain, or allow to be kept on the premises occupied by anyone within the corporate limits of the city, or allow to go or run at large within the corporate limits of the city, any dog not vaccinated and tagged. (Code 1967, § 4-31) Sec. 4-57. - Dogs at large; leashes required. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or keeping any dog in the city to allow such dog to run at large upon the streets, sidewalks and public areas of the city unless such dog shall be secured by a leash controlled by a person competent to hold, manage and control such dog while so leashed. (Code 1967, § 4-33) Sec. 4-58. - Dogs on private property. It shall be lawful for any person to keep a dog without a leash so long as such dog is restrained or contained on the private property of the owner of such premises. (Code 1967, § 4-34) Sec. 4-59. - Impounding of unleashed dogs running at large; redemption by owner. (a) Whenever any dog is found running at large, not under leash, and being off the premises of the owner or keeper of such dog, then the duly authorized agents or employees of the city shall be authorized to catch and confine such dog and after confining such dog for a period of not less than three (3) days to dispose of such dog so confined in a humane manner. (b) The owner of any dog confined or impounded, as provided in subsection (a), may reclaim such dog by making claim at the Valley Humane Society or any other authorized agent acting on behalf of the city and paying such redemption fees as may be required by that agent. (Code 1967, § 4-35) Sec. 4-60. - Penalty for violating sections 4-57 through 4-59. The owner of any dog convicted of violation of sections 4-57 through 4-59 shall on conviction be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-14. (Code 1967, § 4-37) Secs. 4-61—4-75. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-2008, § 1, adopted Oct. 13, 2008, deleted art. III, div. 2, in its entirety which pertained to dangerous dogs. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. ARTICLE IV. - ANIMAL CONTROL[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Aug. 9, 2010, repealed former Art. IV, §§ 4-76—4-92, and enacted a new Art. IV as set out herein. Former Art. IV pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 10-2008, § 1, 10-13-08.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-76. - Definitions. As defined and used in this article, when used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Animal bite means a seizing by an animal with the teeth or jaws of such animal so that a person or other animal has been nipped, gripped, wounded, or pierced. Animal control officer means that person designated by the chief of police of the city to carry out and enforce the provisions of this article. In the absence of such designation, the chief of police shall be deemed the animal control officer. Animal shelter means a facility designated by the city council and used to temporarily confine and house animals that have been seized or confiscated. Complaint means any written or oral report of an incident or condition alleged to be in violation of this article or any written or oral request for action under or compliance with the provisions of this article. Dog at large means that a dog is on any public street, alley, park, or other public grounds, or that a dog is off the premises of the owner or person who has custody of the dog, and not constrained by a leash or under the immediate control of the owner or person who has custody of the dog. Domestic animal means an animal that is a member of a species, which through long association with man, has been bred to a degree which has resulted in changes affecting the temperament, color, conformation, or other attributes of the species to an extent that makes animals of the species unique and different from wild individuals of their kind. Exotic animals means animals that do not occur naturally, either presently or historically, in the United States. Exposed to rabies means that a person or animal has been seized with the teeth or claws of another animal, so that the skin of the person or animal seized has been nipped or gripped, or has been wounded or pierced and includes suspected or confirmed contact of saliva of the seizing animal with a break or abrasion of the skin or with any mucous membrane of the person or animal seized, as determined by a licensed physician. Guard dog means a dog which is trained or used for the express purpose of protecting and guarding property. Guide dog means a dog, especially trained for the purpose, that is used as a guide to ambulation by a person who is totally or partially blind. Hearing dog means a dog, especially trained for the purpose, that is used as a guide to ambulation by a person who is hearing impaired. Licensed veterinarian means a veterinarian duly licensed to practice veterinary medicine in any state. Livestock or farm animal means any animal that is considered livestock or a farm animal, such as chickens, horses, mares, jacks, jennies, colts, cows, calves, yearlings, bulls, oxen, sheep, goats, lambs, hogs, shoats and pigs. Mauling means the infliction of a serious injury by an animal to a human or another animal. A mauling is differentiated from a bite by the degree of injury. Serious injury differentiates a bite from a mauling Native animals mean animals that occur naturally, either presently or historically, in the United States and its territories. In addition, native wild animals include those animals introduced into the United States that have become widespread and are generally considered native. Neutered means made incapable of sexually reproducing offspring (male animals). Nuisance means an incident or episode whereby an animal: (1) Is allowed to act or perform in such a manner as to cause damage or unsanitary conditions to public property or to the property of another. (2) Enters any place where food is stored, prepared, served, or sold to the public, except guide dogs that are accompanying a totally or partially blind person and hearing dogs that accompany a hearing impaired person. (3) Chases, runs after, or jumps at vehicles using public streets or alleys. (4) Feeds from, turns over, or otherwise disturbs garbage containers. (5) Scratches or digs in flower beds, gardens or soil, or damages the property of persons other than the owner. (6) Is allowed to mate in full or partial view of the public, except for animals inside enclosures designed to keep mating from unwanted public viewing. (7) Disturbs the peace by constantly or incessantly barking or howling, or by constantly or incessantly making other disturbing noises. (8) Running at large. Owner means any person having a right of property of the animal, or who keeps or harbors the animal, or who has it in his care (to include feeding the animal), or acts as its custodian, or who permits the animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by such person. Potentially vicious animal means: (1) Any animal of any species, domestic or wild, native or exotic where a report has been filed or a complaint made about or concerning the animal with the police department and evidence shows the animal to have behaved in a threatening manner, without provocation, toward humans, or which habitually snaps, growls, snarls, jumps upon or otherwise threatens persons who are lawfully using public sidewalks, streets, alleys, parks, recreation fields, or other public place; or (2) Any animal of the following breed or one that has the appearance and characteristics of or a combination of any of those breeds according to the standards established by the American Kennel Club or the United Kennel Club, excluding bona fide guide dogs, dogs used for search and rescue, or dogs used in law enforcement: a. Pit bull dog, Bull Terrier, American Pit Bull Terrier, the American Staffordshire Terrier, or a Presa Canario. b. Rottweiler. c. Chow Chow. d. Doberman Pinscher. e. German Shepherd. f. Wolf-hybrid. Restraint/enclosure means when any of the following conditions exist: (1) The animal is confined in a building, fenced pen or yard, electrified fence, or electronic fence on its owner's property or on the property of another person with the other person's consent, adequate to prevent contact with the general public or any persons who enter the premises with the actual or implied permission of the owner or keeper of the animal. (2) The animal, when off the premises of the owner, is under the immediate and effective control of a responsible person adequately restrained by leash sufficient to prevent the animal from engaging any other human or animal. Running at large means any dog not within a proper enclosure or under adequate restraint as defined by this article. Spayed means made incapable of sexually reproducing offspring (female animals). Stray means any dog not tagged with a rabies inoculation tag and/or a personal identification tag. Vaccination means the administration of anti-rabies vaccines or other vaccines by any licensed veterinarian or his authorized representative at such intervals as required by state law. Vicious animal means any animal of any species, domestic or wild, native or exotic that: (1) Attacks a human being or other domestic animal without provocation, provided that the animal shall not be deemed vicious if the threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner or keeper of the dog, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal, or has in the past, abused or assaulted the animal or was committing or attempting to commit a crime, as long as the owner was not aware of the current or past provocation and failed to take actions to stop the provocations, or; (2) According to the records of the city police or a county law enforcement agency, has inflicted injury on a human being without provocation, or; (3) According to the records of the city police or a county law enforcement agency, has killed a domestic animal without provocation while off the owner's property, or; (4) Is harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting or any animal trained for fighting. Wild animals means animals other than those defined as domestic, including mammals, birds, reptiles, and amphibians, which are either native or exotic. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-77. - Tethering of animals. It shall be unlawful to tether any animal on a chain, rope or cable. All animals shall be housed indoors or in a secure outdoor area that allows for free movement sufficient for the animal's size. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-78. - Humane care of animals. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to overload, maim, tease, torture, or abuse any animal. No animal may be intentionally killed unless the animal is injured and/or is destroyed according to this article. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive any animal of shelter which shall protect the animal from the elements. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive any animal of necessary medical attention when the animal is in a condition in which failure to provide medical attention would result in death or unreasonable pain or suffering. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive any animal of sufficient food and water as often as the feeding habits of such animal require to prevent dehydration, starvation or a significant risk to the animal's health from lack of food or water. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person to put out or cause to be put out any poison within the city for the purpose of harming any domesticated animal. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person to release or leave any animal on any private or public property with the intention of abandoning such animal. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-79. - Restriction on number of dogs. Not more than four (4) dogs shall be allowed in or on any residence of the owner or the person who has custody of the dogs, except by special approval by the city council, or except for a mother animal temporarily nursing a large litter of recently born puppies. The police department and/or authorized agent shall investigate the residence applying for a variance to this section before the presentation of the special application to the council. This restriction shall not apply to kennels or other dog-related businesses that are licensed and permitted according to federal and/or state and/or municipal statutes. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-80. - Licensing (potentially vicious or vicious animal). (a) In order to insure and monitor compliance with the requirements of this article no potentially vicious or vicious animal shall be kept, harbored or maintained in the city unless such animal has been registered by the owner with the city clerk. (b) Each registration shall include: (1) Owner's name. (2) Owner's address. (3) Owner's telephone number. (4) Name of the animal. (5) Breed, color, gender, and distinguishing marks of the animal. (6) Physical address where the animal will be housed. (7) Proof of inoculation and tag. (8) Proof of liability insurance or adequate surety bond as required in this article. (9) Proof of proper enclosure as required in this article. (10) Proof of spaying or neutering of vicious dog. (Not required for potentially vicious dog). (c) Each dog required to be licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article shall at all times wear a secure collar or harness with a tag securely fastened thereon indicating the name and address of the owner, the type or breed of the animal, that the animal has been duly registered, and the date of such registration. The license issued hereunder shall not be transferable from animal to animal or from owner to owner. (d) The fee for licensing pursuant to this article shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-81. - Dog owner liability insurance; surety bond. (a) A policy of insurance or surety bond in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of each potentially vicious animal against liability for personal injuries or property damage inflicted by the potentially vicious animal. (b) A policy of insurance or surety bond shall be required in the amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of each vicious animal against liability for personal injuries or property damage inflicted by the vicious animal. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-82. - Landlord dog owner liability insurance; surety bond. (a) Landlords renting property to a person who owns, houses, maintains, or in any way keeps on the landlord's rental property a dog listed defined as potentially vicious or vicious by this article shall maintain a policy of insurance or surety bond in addition to the policy of insurance or surety bond required to be maintained by the dog owner. This liability insurance or surety bond shall be in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the landlord who rents to the owner of each potentially vicious animal against liability for personal injuries or property damage inflicted by the vicious animal. (b) Landlords renting property to a person who owns, houses, maintains, or in any way keeps on the landlord's rental property a dog listed defined as vicious by this article shall maintain a policy of insurance or surety bond in addition to the policy of insurance or surety bond required to be maintained by the dog owner. This liability insurance or surety bond shall be in the amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the landlord who rents to the owner of each vicious animal against liability for personal injuries or property damage inflicted by the vicious animal. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-83. - Proper enclosure for potentially vicious or vicious animal. (a) Every owner of any animal declared a potentially vicious or a vicious animal shall at all times maintain for said animal a proper enclosure. A proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping which shall keep an animal while on the owner's or landlord's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed or locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of younger children and designed to prohibit the dog from escaping said enclosure. Any such enclosure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and if the animal is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom and top of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the animal from escaping either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the animal. (b) At any time that a vicious or potentially vicious animal is not confined in a proper enclosure as described herein, the animal shall be muzzled in such a manner as to prevent it from biting or injuring any person or animal, and kept on a leash with the owner or custodian in attendance having immediate physical control of the leash. (c) An exception to this article is hereby provided for any potentially vicious or vicious animal being attended to by a veterinary professional, or while participating in any lawful animal show, contest or exhibition. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-84. - Mandatory spaying/neutering. (a) Subject to the express exceptions provided in subsection (2) below, it shall be unlawful to keep, harbor or maintain in the city any unspayed or unneutered animal declared a vicious animal that is over four (4) months of age. (b) The prohibition set forth in subsection (1) above shall not apply if a veterinarian licensed in this state shall certify in writing that a specific animal declared a potentially vicious or vicious animal is medically unfit to undergo the required spay or neuter procedure because of a physical condition which would be substantially aggravated by such procedure or would likely cause the animal's death. Such writing shall also include a description of the likely duration of the physical condition which prohibits the procedure. As soon as such condition ceases to exist, it shall be the duty of the owner or person who harbors or keeps such animal to promptly comply with this article. (c) Failure to comply with this code section of this article may result in the unsprayed/unneutered animal declared a potentially vicious or a vicious animal being seized and impounded at an authorized animal shelter and retained for ten (10) days, during which time the owner may reclaim the animal upon proof of arrangements to comply with this article. Should the owner fail to make and give proper notice of the arrangements to comply with this article within ten (10) days from impoundment, the animal shall be destroyed. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-85. - Impoundment. (a) Any dog not properly insured, licensed, vaccinated or not wearing a collar with the proper information stated earlier in this article, found abandoned, or not under restraint, may be seized and impounded by the proper authority. Dogs found not on a restraint may be released to the owner if the owner can be reasonably found and time permits with only a warning or citation, depending on the circumstances. (b) Animals impounded will be transported to an animal shelter under contract with the City of West Point to be disposed of (adoption, euthanized, etc.) pursuant to the policies of that shelter. (c) An owner, keeper, custodian, or person redeeming a currently licensed animal from the authorized animal shelter shall furnish proof of current rabies vaccination and current license specifically applicable to the animal being redeemed. Such owner, keeper, custodian, or responsible person shall also present to the animal shelter an authorization for release issued by the city clerk at the time the authorization issued is redeemed. Upon presentation of the authorization for release and upon payment of the boarding charges to the animal shelter by the owner, keeper, custodian, or responsible person, the animal may be released to the owner or guardian of the impounded animal. A release fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) must be paid to the city clerk, or his or her representative, prior to the release. (d) A dog for which a license is required, but whose license has expired, a currently unlicensed dog, defined as a dog wearing one (1) or both of its required tags, but at least one (1) has expired, or a stray dog may be released from impoundment to its owner under the following conditions: (1) The owner must pay the regular boarding charge to the facility where the animal is confined. (2) If the animal has a city license, but does not have a current rabies vaccination, the owner must take the animal to a licensed veterinarian or his authorized representative for the vaccination. (3) The owner must then show proof of the vaccination to the animal control officer, rabies control officer, the health officer, or the city clerk. (4) If the owner has a current rabies vaccination, but is not required to have city license, the owner only has to show proof of the vaccination to the city clerk. (e) Stray animals that are impounded will be housed at the animal shelter for a maximum of seven (7) days. Any stray not claimed after seven (7) days may be euthanized at the discretion of the animal shelter. If an animal is claimed by the owner, prior to being euthanized, the owner will be responsible for all fees associated with the housing and care of the animal or animals. (f) Vicious animals or potentially vicious animals that are impounded will be housed at the animal shelter for a maximum of twenty-one (21) days. Any vicious or potentially vicious animal not claimed after twenty-one (21) days may be euthanized at the discretion of the animal shelter. If a vicious or potentially vicious animal is claimed by the owner prior to being euthanized, the owner will be responsible for all fees associated with the housing and care of the animal or animals. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-86. - Fines. (a) Animal control officers, city police officers, deputy sheriffs, and/or marshals are empowered to issue citations to the owners, keepers, custodians, or persons responsible for animals when such owners, keepers, custodians, or persons responsible are in violation of this article. Upon an adjudication that such owners, keepers, custodians, or persons responsible are in violation hereof, the following minimum fines shall be assessed: (1) The owner, keeper, custodian, or person responsible for dogs not licensed, vaccinated, or not wearing a collar, running at large, or is declared a nuisance shall be fined with the fine for the first violation being fifty dollars ($50.00), the fine for the second violation being one hundred fifty-four dollars ($154.00), the fine for the third violation being two hundred forty-eight dollars ($248.00). After a third violation, the animal may be declared a habitual nuisance by the animal control officer or chief of police, and the owner, keeper, custodian, or responsible person shall be required to permanently remove the animal from the city. (2) The owner, keeper, custodian, or person responsible for vicious or potentially vicious animals not properly insured shall be fined with the fine for the first violation being two hundred forty-eight dollars ($248.00), the fine for the second violation being five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a third violation being five hundred dollars ($500.00) and the confiscation of the dog. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-87. - Injured animal. If an animal is struck and injured by a vehicle or is suffering from another cause and it is deemed by a licensed veterinarian, animal control officer, police officer, deputy sheriff, or marshal to be beyond help, the animal may be humanely destroyed without a period of confinement. In such cases, it shall be the responsibility of the animal's owner to dispose of the animal's carcass in a manner that meets state and federal health regulations. If the owner of the animal cannot be determined, the city shall be responsible for properly disposing of the carcass. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-88. - Animal bite. Any person bitten or mauled by an animal shall notify the police department for the completion of an incident report. Attempts will be made to locate and capture the animal involved in the bite. If captured, the animal shall be required to be quarantined for a period of at least ten (10) days in a proper enclosure as defined in this ordinance or other enclosure that will not allow the animal contact with humans or other animals. If the chief of police, animal control officer, county marshal, or other law enforcement officer has reason to believe that it is in the best interest of the city for the animal to be housed at a veterinary clinic or other facility, any cost for this housing and care will be the responsibility of the owner. Such cost must be paid prior to the animal's release from such care. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-89. - Potentially vicious or vicious animals off premises of owner, etc. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor a potentially vicious or a vicious animal in the City of West Point, Georgia unless all provisions of this article are met. (b) Any potentially vicious or vicious animal whose owner, keeper, custodian, or responsible person is not in compliance with this article or found off the premises of its owner, keeper, or custodian, may be seized by any police officer, animal control officer, deputy, marshal, or any other authorized agent of the City of West Point and, upon establishing the vicious character of the animal by a court of competent jurisdiction, the animal may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of by state statutes, with the owner being liable for all costs of boarding, treatment, and disposal of the animal. (c) This section shall not apply to animals under the control of law enforcement or military agencies, nor to guard dogs, which are kept for the protection of property by licensed commercial establishments; provided the animal is restrained by an adequate cage or fence (excluding electronic fences) preventing contact with general public or any persons who enter the premises with the actual or implied consent of the owner or keeper of the animal. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-90. - Penalties. Except for warnings described in this article and specific fines set forth above, any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days, plus court cost, as well as the cost of boarding, treatment, and disposal of the animal where applicable. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-91. - Animal control board. The mayor and council shall create an animal control board of sufficient number of persons to hear, and act upon, hearings of animal control issues. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-92. - Hearings. (a) The chief of police of the City of West Point, or his or her designee (such designee specifically to include, but not be limited to the animal control officer), is hereby designated as the person responsible for determining when: (1) A dog is a potentially vicious animal; (2) A dog is a vicious animal; (3) When a dog is a nuisance; (4) A domestic animal is a stray animal; (5) A domestic animal is an injured animal; (6) Any animal's behavior or condition is in violation of any provision of this article; or (7) When any owner, keeper, custodian or responsible person for an animal is in violation of this article. (b) Any determination by the chief of police, or his or her designee, of any of the conditions or violations set forth above which will or may result in the destruction or euthanasia of the animal, shall, when feasible or possible, be communicated to the owner, keeper, or custodian of the animal. (c) An appeal of the determination of the chief of police, or his or her designee, shall be to the animal control board. Such appeal must be in writing and must be received by the city clerk within two (2) business days of receipt by the owner, keeper, or custodian of the determination by the chief of police, or his or her designee. (d) The animal control board shall schedule an appeal proceeding to hear the evidence with regard to the determination made by the chief of police, or his or her designee, and to decide the legitimacy of that determination. Such appeal shall be heard within ten (10) business days of the receipt of such written appeal. The animal control board shall adopt, reject, or modify, in its discretion, the determination of the chief of police, or his or her designee. Such decision of the animal control board shall be final. (e) Any person eligible to file an appeal hereunder may sign a waiver of appeal if so desired. In such case, if euthanasia would be the final result of the determination by the chief of police, or his or her designee, the animal may be euthanized and no additional costs will accrue to the owner, keeper, or custodian. (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10) Sec. 4-93. - Compliance. (a) Animals will not be released from confinement until proof of vaccination is demonstrated. (b) Persons advised of violations of the following violations will be provided thirty (30) days to come within compliance: (1) The necessity for insurance. (2) Tethering of an animal. (3) Restriction on the number of dogs. (4) Licensing. (5) Proper enclosure. (6) Mandatory spaying or neutering (vicious dog only). (Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1(Exh. A), 8-9-10)

div.head: Chapter 5 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— A 1989 amendment to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25 provides for the statewide implementation of various standard building codes after October 1, 1991. The building codes and regulations adopted in the 1967 Code remain in effect pending implementation of the 1989 amendment, and copies are available for inspection in the clerk-treasurer's office and the office of the code enforcement officer. Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; floodplain regulations, Ch. 9; sewerage, Ch. 13; soil erosion and sedimentation control, Ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 17; subdivisions, Ch. 18; utilities, Ch. 21; zoning, App. A. State Law reference— Governing body may enact standards to determine safety of buildings, Ga. Const. art. 1, sec. 4, par. 1; authority of city or county to provide codes, including building, housing, plumbing and electrical codes, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(12); adoption and continuation of state minimum standard codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-21; state-wide application of minimum standard codes, codes requiring adoption by municipality or county, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7.
Sec. 5-1. - Fire limits. All that portion of the city embraced in the following named boundaries shall be designated the fire limits: On the east by the Chattahoochee River; on the north by West 13th Street and the line formed by extending West 13th Street in an easterly direction to a point of intersection with the Chattahoochee River; on the west by the east margin of 5th Avenue to the point where said east margin of 5th Avenue intersects with the Alabama State Line; on the west and south by the Alabama State Line. (Code 1967, § 5-1) Sec. 5-2. - Abatement of nuisances. Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to mean that public nuisances by the common law, by statute, and such as are nuisances per se, can not be abated by the duly constituted municipal authorities of the city without notice and a hearing, where such nuisances exist or are maintained within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1967, § 5-3) Sec. 5-3. - Code enforcement officer; compensation. (a) The council shall elect a code enforcement officer for a term coextensive with their term of office at a salary to be fixed by the council; provided, however, that if the council should elect some person holding an office, or who is an employee of the city, already receiving a salary or other compensation from the city, the council shall not be required to pay the code enforcement officer any salary or other compensation in addition to that which he is already receiving as such officer or employee. (b) The code enforcement officer assumes the duties of the former building inspector and gas inspector and is responsible for enforcing the following codes: (1) Standard Building Code (SBCCI) (2) Standard Gas Code (SBCCI) (3) Standard Mechanical Code (SBCCI) (4) Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code (SBCCI) (Code 1967, § 5-4) Sec. 5-4. - Reserved. Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Mar. 11, 1991, set out provisions codified in Art. II which in effect repealed § 5-4. Section 5-4 pertained to the unsafe building abatement code and derived from and ordinance adopted Oct. 9, 1989, §§ 1, 2. Sec. 5-5. - Plumber's license required. Every person employed or working as a plumber shall file written application with the city for a license to engage in such work in the city. No person shall connect or cause to be connected any plumbing work with the city water mains or with the city sewer system, without first having filed the above application, and been granted a license by the city to work as a plumber. (Code 1967, § 18-2) Sec. 5-6. - Allowing one's name, license or bond to be used to obtain permit fraudulently. No person engaged in the business of plumbing or drain laying shall allow his name to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a permit or for the construction of any work under his license or bond, under penalty of forfeiture of his license. (Ord. of 9-10-90; Ord. of 11-11-96) Sec. 5-10. - Temporary structures. (a) Permit required, application requirements. (1) Temporary structures, including, but not limited to: tents, canopies, sheds, awnings and lean-to's; shall not be erected in the city without first obtaining a permit from the mayor and aldermen. Applications for permits to erect temporary structures shall be made in writing to the city clerk-treasurer. Such applications will be heard at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the mayor and aldermen, provided they are submitted at least ten (10) days prior to the date they are to be heard. Applications will include the following: a. Name, address and telephone number of applicant; b. Size and complete description of structure to be erected; c. Purpose for which structure will be used; d. Estimated date upon which structure will be completely erected; e. Date that structure will be removed from premises; f. Location of property where the temporary structure will be placed, including the name and address of owner; g. Zoning district of such location. (2) Permits for temporary structures shall be issued for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. (b) Exceptions. Permits for temporary structures shall not be required under the following circumstances: (1) The structure is erected for the purpose of sheltering a wedding, funeral, yard sale, bake sale or other civic, religious or family gathering and the structure is erected for a period no longer than forty-eight (48) hours; (2) The structure is located on residential property and is used only for recreational purposes for a period of seven (7) days or less. (c) Hearing, issuance of permit, revocation for cause. Upon approval by the mayor and aldermen a permit will be issued, provided that the necessary information has been submitted by the applicant to insure that the proposed structure will comply with all applicable codes and ordinances of the city. Such permit will only remain valid for the time limit indicated, and the temporary structure must be completely removed from the premises upon expiration of the permit. A temporary structure permit may be revoked for cause. (d) Extensions, advertisement. The time limit of a temporary structure permit may be extended only by the express approval of the mayor and aldermen. Applications for an extension of time will be in the same form as the original application. Applications for a time extension to a temporary structure permit must be advertised in the Valley Times-News, a newspaper published in Lanett, Chambers County, Alabama, and having general circulation in the city, in each of the two (2) weeks preceding the meeting of the mayor and aldermen during which they will heard. Applications for a time extension must be heard prior to expiration of the original permit. After hearing the request of the applicant and any public comment the mayor and aldermen may authorize extension of the temporary structure permit by any period deemed appropriate. (e) Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 of this Code. (Ord. of 7-8-96) Secs. 5-11—5-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UNSAFE OR UNFIT BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-9, § 1, adopted November 12, 2018, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 5-26—5-33.1, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to unfit structures and derived from Ord. of 3-11-91, §§ 1—9; Ord. No. 2010-05, Exh. A, 6-14-10.
Sec. 5-26. - Findings of the existence of nuisance structures. (a) The governing authority of the city finds and declares that within the corporate limits of the city there is the existence or occupancy of dwellings or other buildings or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business occupancy or use and are not in compliance with applicable state minimum standard codes as adopted by ordinance or operation of law or any optional building, fire, life safety, or other codes relative to the safe use of real property and real property improvements adopted by ordinance to be in force within the city; or general nuisance law and which constitute a hazard to the health, safety, and welfare of the people of the city and the state; and that the public necessity exists for the repair, closing, or demolition of such dwellings, buildings, or structures. (b) It is further found and declared that within the corporate limits of the city where there is in existence a condition or use of real estate which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation, such use is dangerous and injurious to the health, safety, and welfare of the people of the city and a public necessity exists for the repair of such condition or the cessation of such use which renders the adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation. Moreover, the mayor and council find that there exist in the city dwellings, buildings, or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business uses due to dilapidation and which are not in compliance with applicable codes; which have defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; which lack adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; or other conditions exist rendering such dwellings, buildings or structure unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city, or vacant, dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures in which drug crimes are being committed. Finally, it is the intent of the governing authority to invoke the procedures hereafter codified for private property which constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions to those persons residing or working in the vicinity of the property. (Ord. No. 18-9, § 1, 11-12-18) Sec. 5-27. - Nuisance abatement procedures. (a) Continued use of other laws and ordinances. It is the intent of the mayor and council that nothing in this article shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of any local enabling act, charter, ordinance or regulation nor to prevent or punish violations thereof; and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law or ordinance, legislation, or regulation. (b) Definitions. Applicable codes means (a) any optional housing or abatement standard provided in Chapter 2 of Title 8 of the O.C.G.A. as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or other property maintenance standards as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or general nuisance law, relative to the safe use of real property; (b) any fire or life safety code as provided for in Chapter 2 of Title 25 of the O.C.G.A.; and (c) any building codes adopted by local ordinance prior to October 1, 1991, or the minimum standard codes provided in O.C.G.A. Chapter 2 of Title 8 after October 1 provided that such building or minimum standard codes for real property improvements shall be deemed to mean those building or minimum standard codes in existence at the time such real property improvements were constructed unless otherwise provided by law. Closing means causing a dwelling, building, or structure to be vacated and secured against unauthorized entry. Drug crime means an act which is a violation of O.C.G.A. Article 2 of Chapter 13 of Title 16, known as the Georgia Controlled Substances Act. Dwellings, buildings, or structures means any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses, improvements, and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. The term "dwellings, buildings, or structures" shall not mean or include any farm, any building or structure located on a farm, or any agricultural facility or other building or structure used for the production, growing, raising, harvesting, storage, or processing of crops, livestock, poultry, or other farm products. Governing authority means the Mayor and Council of the City of West Point. Interested party means: (1) Owner; (2) Those parties having an interest in the property as revealed by a certification of title to the property conducted in accordance with the title standards of the State Bar of Georgia; (3) Those parties having filed a notice in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-3-9; (4) Any other party having an interest in the property whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable from the records of the city or records maintained in the county courthouse or by the clerk of court. Interested party shall not include the holder of the benefit or burden of any easement or right-of-way whose interest is properly recorded which interest shall remain unaffected; and (5) Persons in possession of said property and premises. Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. Public authority means any member of a governing authority, any housing authority officer, or any officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the government of the municipality, county, or state relating to health, fire, or building regulations or to other activities concerning dwellings, buildings, or structures in the county or municipality. Public officer means the officer or officers who are authorized by O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7, § 41-2-8 and §§ 41-2-9 through 41-2-17 and by this article adopted under § 41-2-7, § 41-2-8, and §§ 41-2-9 through 41-2-17 to exercise the powers prescribed by this article or any agent of such officer or officers. Repair means altering or improving a dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes in the jurisdiction where the property is located and the cleaning or removal of debris, trash, and other materials present and accumulated which create a health or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building, or structure. Resident means any person residing in the jurisdiction where the property is located on or after the date on which the alleged nuisance arose. (c) Duties of owners; appointment of public officer; procedures for determining premises to be unsafe or unhealthful. (1) It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure, or property within the jurisdiction to construct and maintain such dwelling, building, structure, or property in conformance with applicable codes in force within the city, or such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on property and which declare it to be a public nuisance to construct or maintain any dwelling, building, structure or property in violation of such codes or ordinances; (2) The Mayor and Council of the City of West Point hereby appoint and designate the public works director and his designee(s) as the public officer(s) to exercise the powers prescribed by this article. (d) Other remedies not precluded. (1) The public officers designated herein may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety, and other codes adopted by ordinance, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and may seek to enforce such citation in courts of competent jurisdiction prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this article. (2) Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. (Ord. No. 18-9, § 1, 11-12-18) Sec. 5-28. - Procedures; notice; hearing; appeal. (a) Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority or by at least five (5) residents of the city charging that any dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific dwelling, building, structure, or property. If the officer's investigation or inspection identifies that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the interested parties in such dwelling, building, or structure. The complaint shall identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; identify the interested parties; state with particularity the factual basis for the action; and contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance. The summons shall notify the interested parties that a hearing will be held before the Municipal Court of the City of West Point, at a date and time certain and at a place within the city where the property is located. Such hearing shall be held not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than forty-five (45) days after the filing of said complaint in court. The interested parties shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing. (b) If after such notice and hearing, the court determines that the dwelling, building, or structure in question is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: (1) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; (2) If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property; (3) For purposes of this article, the court shall make its determination of reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however; that costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be factored in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a Georgia appraiser classification as provided in Chapter 39A of Title 31, of the O.C.G.A. qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violations in force in the jurisdiction. (c) If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved, or to be vacated and closed, or demolished. Such abatement shall commence within two hundred seventy (270) days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. Any time during which such action is prohibited by a court order issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13 or any other equitable relief granted by the court of competent jurisdiction shall not be counted toward the two hundred seventy (270) days in which such abatement action must commence. The public officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the dwelling, building or structure a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use and connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." (d) If the public officer has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The public officer and the city are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials; and (e) The amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees and administrative costs incurred by the municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (1) The lien provided for in subsection (e) of this section shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure or demolition in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under subsection (d) of section 14-264. The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. (2) Upon final determination of costs, fees and expenses incurred in accordance with this chapter, the public officer responsible for enforcement actions in accordance with this chapter shall transmit to the appropriate municipal tax collector or city revenue officer a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to interested parties. The statement of the public officer shall be transmitted within ninety (90) days of completion of the repairs, demolition or closure. It shall be the duty of the appropriate municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, whose duties include the collection of municipal taxes, to collect the amount of the lien using methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes, including specifically O.C.G.A. Tit. 48, Ch. 4 provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires twelve (12) months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. The municipal tax collection or city revenue officer shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the city. (3) Enforcement of liens pursuant to this article may be initiated at any time following receipt by the municipal tax collector or city revenue officer of the final determination of costs in accordance with this article. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. An enforcement proceeding pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 for delinquent ad valorem taxes may include all amounts due under this article. (4) The redemption amount of any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this section shall be the full amount of costs as finally determined in accordance with this section together with interest, penalties and costs incurred by the governing authority, municipal tax collector or city revenue officer in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien may be made in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. (f) Where the abatement action does not commence in the superior court, review of a court order requiring the repair, alteration, improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building, or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court under O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. (Ord. No. 18-9, § 1, 11-12-18) Sec. 5-29. - Standards; powers; service of complaints. (a) The public officer may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use if he/she finds that conditions exist in such building, dwelling, or structure which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety, or morals of the occupants of such dwelling, building, or structure; of the occupants of neighborhood dwelling, buildings, or structures; or of other residents of the city. Such conditions may include the following (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): (1) Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; (2) Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; (3) Dilapidation; (4) Disrepair; (5) Structural defects; (6) Uncleanliness; and (7) Other additional standards which may from time to time by adopted and referenced herein by ordinance amendment. The public officer may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes based upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. (b) The public officer(s) designated in this article shall have such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this ordinance, including the following powers: (1) To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings, building, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial, or business use or are vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; (2) To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; (3) To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; (4) To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he or she deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the ordinance; and (5) To delegate any of his or her functions and powers under the ordinance to such officers and agents as he or she may designate. (c) Service of complaints. (1) Complaints issued by a public officer pursuant to this article shall be served in the following manner. At least fourteen (14) days prior to the date of the hearing, the public officer shall mail copies of the complaint by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to all interested parties whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable. Copies of the complaint shall also be mailed by first class mail to the attention of the occupants of the property, if any, and shall be posted on the property within three (3) business days of filing the complaint and at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date of the hearing. (2) For interested parties whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriffs advertisements appear in Troup County once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. (d) A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county in which the dwelling, building, or structure is located at the time of filing the complaint in the appropriate court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. (e) As provided by O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13, any person affected by an order issued by the public officer may petition to the superior court for an injunction restraining the public officer from carrying out the provisions of the order and the court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the public officer pending the final disposition of the cause; provided, however, that such person shall present such petition to the court within fifteen (15) days of the posting and service of the order of the public officer. De novo hearings shall be had by the court on petitions within twenty (20) days. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require; provided, however, that it shall not be necessary to file bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction under this Code section. (f) Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint and hearing shall be served in the manner provided in this section on any interested party who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any interested party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. (Ord. No. 18-9, § 1, 11-12-18) Secs. 5-30—5-33. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - COMPATIBILITY STANDARDS FOR MANUFACTURED HOMES
Sec. 5-34. - Definitions. (a) Manufactured home. A structure, transportable in one (1) or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight (8) body feet or more in width or forty (40) body feet or more in length, when erected on site, is three hundred twenty (320) or more square feet in floor area, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; or a structure that otherwise comes within the definition of a manufactured home under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, as amended (42 U.S.C. 5401-5445). (b) Architectural features. Ornamental or decorative features attached to or protruding from an exterior wall, including cornices, eaves, gutters, belt courses, sills, lintels, bay windows, chimneys, and decorative ornaments. (c) Bay window. A window assembly whose maximum horizontal projection is not more that two (2) feet from the vertical plane of an exterior wall and is elevated above the floor level of the home. (d) Compatibility. With regard to buildings, compatibility means achieving harmony in appearance or architectural features in the same vicinity. (e) Dormer. A window projecting from a roof. (f) Eave. The projecting lower edges of a roof overhanging the wall of a building. (Ord. of 9-9-02, § 4) Sec. 5-35. - Building permit required. No manufactured home shall be installed on any site, nor shall any such manufactured home be occupied or used for any purpose until and unless the building official issues a permit. The building official shall not issue a permit for installing, occupying, or using a manufactured home unless it is in conformity with all the provisions of this chapter and the zoning ordinance of the city. (Ord. of 9-9-02, § 4) Sec. 5-36. - Basic installation requirements. (a) Foundation. Each manufactured home must be set on an appropriate permanent foundation. (b) Hauling mechanisms removed. The transportation mechanisms, including wheels, axles, and hitch, must be removed prior to occupancy. (c) Installation regulations. The manufactured home shall be installed in accordance with the installation instructions from the manufacturer, as appropriate. (d) Approved septic system. Each manufactured home shall be connected to a public sanitary sewer system, community sewerage system, or on-site septic system with capacity available as approved by the health officer or other appropriate city or county official. (Ord. of 9-9-02, § 4) Sec. 5-37. - Construction standards. (a) Applicability. These standards shall apply to insure architectural harmony of manufactured homes and nearby site-built homes and other land uses. (b) Skirting. The entire perimeter area between the bottom of the structure of each manufactured home and the ground, including stairways, shall be underpinned with brick, masonry, finished concrete or siding (of like or similar character to the manufactured home) that completely encloses the perimeter of the undercarriage and attached stairways except for proper ventilation and access openings. (c) Exterior finish. The exterior siding of the manufactured home shall consist of wood or hardboard siding material. (d) Roof pitch and materials. The manufactured home shall have a pitched roof with a slope of at least four (4) feet in height for each twelve (12) feet in width. Roof materials shall wood shake, tile, or asphalt shingle material. (e) Width. The manufactured home shall consist of two (2) fully enclosed parallel sections with a total width of at least twenty (20) feet. (f) Covered porch. A covered porch or deck with a minimum ten-foot depth shall be constructed along the entire length of the manufacture home facing the front yard or street prior to occupancy. (g) Additional architectural features. The manufactured home shall contain eaves with a minimum projection of six (6) inches, window shutters, and at least one (1) additional architectural feature such as dormers, bay windows, or another architectural feature that will provide equal compatibility with surrounding residences and land uses, as approved by the building official. (Ord. of 9-9-02, § 4) Secs. 5-38—5-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 1. - PURPOSE AND SCOPE
Sec. 5-46. - Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide for the administration and enforcement of the Georgia State Minimum Standard Codes as allowed heretofore adopted. Herein after all of the Codes heretofore adopted shall be referred to as the "technical codes," as may be adopted by the state or local jurisdiction. (Ord. of 4-9-07) Sec. 5-47. - Code remedial. (a) General. These codes are hereby-declared to be remedial, and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof - which are public safety, health, and general welfare—through structural strength, stability, sanitation, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and other hazards attributed to the built environment including alteration, repair, removal, demolition, use and occupancy of buildings, structures, or premises, and by regulating the installation and maintenance of all electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems, which may be referred to as service systems. (b) Quality control. Quality control of materials and workmanship is not within the purview of this Code except as it relates to the purposes stated herein. (c) Permitting and inspection. The inspection or permitting of any building, system or plan, under the requirements of this Code shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building, system or plan or their adequacy. The city, nor any employee thereof, shall be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building, system or plan, nor for any failure of any component of such, which may occur subsequent to such inspection or permitting. (Ord. of 4-9-07) Sec. 5-48. - Scope. (a) Applicability: (1) General. Where, in any specific case, different sections of these codes specify different materials, methods of construction or other requirements, the most restrictive shall govern. Where there is a conflict between a general requirement and a specific requirement, the specific requirement shall be applicable. (2) Building. The provisions of the Standard Building Code, as amended, shall apply to the construction, alteration, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, maintenance, removal and demolition, of every building or structure or any appurtenances connected or attached to such buildings or structures. Except in one-and two- family dwellings. (3) Electrical. The provisions of the National Electrical Code, as amended, shall apply to the installation of electrical systems, including alterations, repairs, replacement, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto. (4) Gas. The provisions of the Standard Gas Code, as amended, shall apply to the installation of consumer's gas piping, gas appliances and related accessories as covered in this Code. These requirements apply to gas piping systems extending from the point of delivery to the inlet connections of appliances and the installation and operation of residential and commercial gas appliances and related accessories, except in one and two family dwellings. (5) Mechanical. The provisions of the Standard Mechanical Code, as amended, shall apply to the installation of mechanical systems, including alterations, repairs, replacement, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and/or appurtenances, including ventilating, heating, cooling, air conditioning and refrigeration systems, incinerators, and other energy-related systems. Except in one- and two- family dwellings. (6) Plumbing. The provisions of the Standard Plumbing Code, as amended, shall apply to every plumbing installation, including alterations, repairs, replacement, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances, and when connected to a water or sewerage system. (7) Fire prevention. The provisions of the Standard Fire Prevention Code, as amended, shall apply to the construction, alteration, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, maintenance, of every building or structure or any appurtenances connected or attached to such buildings or structures. (8) Energy. The provisions of the CABO Model Energy Code, as amended, shall regulate the design of building envelopes for adequate thermal resistance and low air leakage and the design and selection of mechanical, electrical, service water heating and illumination systems and equipment that will enable the effective use of energy in new building construction. (9) CABO one- and two- family dwelling.
