A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, or other certifications, or other evidence of compliance required by this chapter is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 2, 7-9-12) Footnotes: --- (2) --- Note— (Definitions containing bracketed areas must be filled in with dates).
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 9-21. - Lands to which this chapter applies. This chapter shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of the City of West Point, Georgia. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(A), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-22. - Basis for area of special flood hazard. The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in its flood insurance study (FIS), dated July 3, 2012*, with accompanying maps and other supporting data and any revision thereto, are adopted by reference and declared a part of this chapter. For those land areas acquired by a municipality through annexation, the current effective FIS dated July 3, 2012*, with accompanying maps and other supporting data and any revision thereto, for (*Troup County and Harris County*) are hereby adopted by reference. Areas of special flood hazard may also include those areas known to have flooded historically or defined through standard engineering analysis by governmental agencies or private parties but not yet incorporated in a FIS. N/A. The repository for public inspection of the flood insurance study (FIS), accompanying maps and other supporting data is located at the City of West Point Technology Center. *Note: Please insert most current FIRM. **Note: These are areas prone to flooding that have not been identified as a special flood hazard area by FEMA but would have to comply with the ordinance standards. Please insert a description or an attached map if such areas exist or insert NA. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(B), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-23. - Establishment of development permit. A development permit shall be required in conformance with the provisions of this chapter PRIOR to the commencement of any development activities. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(C), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-24. - Compliance. No structure or land shall hereafter be located, extended, converted or altered without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(D), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-25. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing ordinance, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this chapter and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(E), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-26. - Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of this chapter all provisions shall be: (1) Considered as minimum requirements; (2) liberally construed in favor of the governing body, and; (3) deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(F), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-27. - Warning and disclaimer of liability. The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. Larger floods can and will occur; flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This chapter does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazard or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This chapter shall not create liability on the part of the City of West Point, or by any officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made hereunder. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(G), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-28. - Penalties for violation. Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter or with any of its requirements, including conditions and safeguards established in connection with grants of variance or special exceptions shall constitute a violation. Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, and in addition, shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Bach day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the City of West Point from taking such other lawful actions as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 3(H), 7-9-12) Secs. 9-29—9-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 9-41. - Designation of ordinance administrator. The building inspector is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 4(A), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-42. - Permit procedures. Application for a development permit shall be made to the building inspector on forms furnished by the community PRIOR to any development activities, and may include, but not be limited to the following: plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the elevations of the area in question and the nature, location, dimensions, of existing or proposed structures, earthen fill placement, storage of materials or equipment, and drainage facilities. Specifically, the following information is required: (1) A pplication stage: a. Elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all proposed structures; b. Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure will be flood-proofed; c. Design certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that any proposed nonresidential flood-proofed structure will meet the flood-proofing criteria of subsection 9-57(2); d. Description of the extent to which any watercourse will be altered or relocated as a result of a proposed development, and; (2) Construction stage: For all new construction and substantial improvements, the permit holder shall provide to the administrator an as-built certification of the regulatory floor elevation or flood-proofing level immediately after the lowest floor or flood-proofing is completed. Any lowest floor certification made relative to mean sea level shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a registered land surveyor or professional engineer and certified by same. When flood-proofing is utilized for nonresidential structures said certification shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a professional engineer or architect and certified by same. **Note: The floodplain administrator has to be a specific position. If someone outside the community will be the floodplain administrator such as the county, an intergovernmental agreement will be required. Any work undertaken prior to submission of these certifications shall be at the permit holder's risk. The building inspector shall review the above referenced certification data submitted. Deficiencies detected by such review shall be corrected by the permit holder immediately and prior to further progressive work being allowed to proceed. Failure to submit certification or failure to make said corrections required hereby shall be cause to issue a stop-work order for the project. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 4(B), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-43. - Duties and responsibilities of the administrator. Duties of the building inspector shall include, but shall not be limited to: (1) Review proposed development to assure that the permit requirements of this chapter have been satisfied; (2) Review proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been received from governmental agencies from which approval is required by federal or state law, including section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334. Require that copies of such permits be provided and maintained on file; (3) Review all permit applications to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding; (4) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 9-22, then the building inspector shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state or other sources in order to administer the provisions of article V; (5) Review and record the actual elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all new or substantially improved structures in accordance with subsection 9-42(2); (6) Review and record the actual elevation, in relation to mean sea level to which any new or substantially improved structures have been flood-proofed, in accordance with subsection 9-42(2); (7) When flood-proofing is utilized for a structure, the building inspector shall obtain certification of design criteria from a registered professional engineer or architect in accordance with subsection 9-42(1)c. and subsection 9-57(2) or 9-59(2); (8) Make substantial damage determinations following a flood event or any other event that causes damage to structures in flood hazard areas; (9) Notify adjacent communities and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA); (10) For any altered or relocated watercourse, submit engineering data/analysis within six (6) months to the FEMA to ensure accuracy of community flood maps through the letter of map revision process. Assure flood-carrying capacity of any altered or relocated watercourse is maintained; (11) Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of boundaries of the areas of special flood hazard (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the building inspector shall make the necessary interpretation. Any person contesting the location of the boundary shall be given a reasonable opportunity to appeal the interpretation as provided in this chapter; and (12) All records pertaining to the provisions of this ordinance shall be maintained in the office of the building inspector and shall be open for public inspection. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 4(C), 7-9-12) Secs. 9-44—9-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PROVISIONS FOR FLOOD HAZARD REDUCTION
Sec. 9-56. - General standards. In ALL areas of special flood hazard the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; (2) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage; (3) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage; (4) Elevated buildings. All new construction and substantial improvements of existing structures that include ANY fully enclosed area located below the lowest floor formed by foundation and other exterior walls shall be designed so as to be an unfinished or flood resistant enclosure. The enclosure shall be designed to equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the automatic entry and exit of floodwater: a. Designs for complying with this requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 1. Provide a minimum of two (2) openings having a total net area of not less than one (1) square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding; 2. The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one-foot above grade; and 3. Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwater in both direction. b. So as not to violate the "lowest floor" criteria of this ordinance, the unfinished or flood resistant enclosure shall only be used for parking of vehicles, limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises, or entry to the elevated area, and c. The interior portion of such enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms; (5) All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding; (6) Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces; (7) New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the system; (8) New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters; (9) On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding, and; (10) Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a structure, which is not compliant with the provisions of this chapter, shall be undertaken only if the nonconformity is not furthered, extended or replaced. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(A), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-57. - Specific standards. In ALL areas of special flood hazard the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and/or substantial improvements . Where base flood elevation data are available, new construction and/or substantial improvement of any structure or manufactured home shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated no lower than one-foot above the base flood elevation. Should solid foundation perimeter walls be used to elevate a structure, openings sufficient to facilitate equalization of flood hydrostatic forces on both sides of exterior walls shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 9-56(4), "elevated buildings". a. All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated at or above one-foot above the base flood elevation. (2) Nonresidential construction. New construction and/or the substantial improvement of any structure located in Al-30, AE, or AH zones, may be flood-proofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to one-foot above the base flood elevation, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and in subsection 9-43(6). (3) Standards for manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. Where base flood elevation data are available: a. All manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved on: (1) Individual lots or parcels, (2) in new and/or substantially improved manufactured home parks or subdivisions, (3) in expansions to existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions, or (4) on a site in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision where a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as the result of a flood, must have the lowest floor including basement, elevated no lower than one-foot above the base flood elevation. b. Manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision may be elevated so that either: 1. The lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated no lower than one-foot above the level of the base flood elevation, or 2. The manufactured home chassis is elevated and supported by reinforced piers (or other foundation elements of at least an equivalent strength) of no less than thirty-six (36) inches in height above grade. c. All manufactured homes must be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. (Reference: Subsection 9-56(6), above.) d. All recreational vehicles placed on sites must either: 1. Be on the site for fewer than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days. 2. Be fully licensed and ready for highway use, (a recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is licensed, on its wheels or jacking system, attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached structures or additions), or 3. The recreational vehicle must meet all the requirements for "new construction", including the anchoring and elevation requirements of subsections 9-57(3)a. and (3)c., above. (4) Floodway. Located within areas of special flood hazard established in section 9-22, are areas designated as floodway. A floodway may be an extremely hazardous area due to velocity floodwaters, debris or erosion potential. In addition, the area must remain free of encroachment in order to allow for the discharge of the base flood without increased flood heights. Therefore, the following provisions shall apply: a. Encroachments are prohibited, including earthen fill, new construction, substantial improvements or other development within the regulatory floodway. Development may be permitted however, provided it is demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels or floodway widths during a base flood discharge. A registered professional engineer must provide supporting technical data and certification thereof. b. ONLY if subsection (4)a. above is satisfied, then any new construction or substantial improvement shall comply with all other applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of article V. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(B), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-58. - Building standards for streams without established base flood elevations and/or floodway (A-Zones). Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 9-22, where streams exist but no base flood data have been provided (A-Zones), or where base flood data have been provided but a floodway has not been delineated, the following provisions apply: (1) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 9-22, then the building inspector shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any scientific or historic base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, in order to administer the provisions of article V. ONLY if data are not available from these sources, then the following provisions (subsections (2) and (3)) shall apply: (2) No encroachments, including structures or fill material, shall be located within an area equal to the width of the stream or twenty (20) feet, whichever is greater, measured from the top of the stream bank, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that such encroachment shall not result in more than a one-foot increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. (3) In special flood hazard areas without base flood elevation data, new construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement) elevated no less than three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. (NOTE: Require the lowest floor to be elevated one-foot above the estimated base flood elevation in A-Zone areas where a Limited Detail Study has been completed). Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 9-56(4) "elevated buildings". a. All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated no less than three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. The building inspector shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(C), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-59. - Standards for areas of special flood hazard (Zones AE) with established base flood elevations without designated floodways. Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 9-22, where streams with base flood elevations are provided but no floodways have been designated, (Zones AE) the following provisions apply: (1) No encroachments, including fill material, new structures or substantial improvements shall be located within areas of special flood hazard, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one (1) foot at any point within the community. The engineering certification should be supported by technical data that conforms to standard hydraulic engineering principles. (2) New construction or substantial improvements of buildings shall be elevated or flood-proofed to elevations established in accordance with section 9-57. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(D), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-60. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO Zones). Areas of special flood hazard established in section 9-22, may include designated "AO" shallow flooding areas. These areas have base flood depths of one (1) to three (3) feet above ground, with no clearly defined channel. The following provisions apply: (1) All new construction and substantial improvements of residential and nonresidential structures shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to the flood depth number specified on the Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), above the highest adjacent grade. If no flood depth number is specified, the lowest floor, including basement, shall be elevated at least three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 9-56(4), "elevated buildings". The building inspector shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (2) New construction or the substantial improvement of a nonresidential structure may be flood-proofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to the specified FIRM flood level plus one (1) foot, above highest adjacent grade, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and as required in subsections 9-42(1)c. and 9-42(2). (3) Drainage paths shall be provided to guide floodwater around and away from any proposed structure. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(E), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-61. - Standards for subdivisions. (a) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; (b) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage; (c) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards, and; (d) For subdivisions and/or developments greater than fifty (50) lots or five (5) acres, whichever is less, base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision and all other proposed development, including manufactured home parks and subdivisions. Any changes or revisions to the flood data adopted herein and shown on the FIRM shall be submitted to FEMA for review as a conditional letter of map revision (CLOMR) or conditional letter of map amendment (CLOMA), whichever is applicable. Upon completion of the project, the developer is responsible for submitting the "as-built" data to FEMA in order to obtain the final LOMR. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(F), 7-9-12) Sec. 9-62. - Standards for critical facilities. (a) Critical facilities shall not be located in the 100-year floodplain or the 500-year floodplain. (b) All ingress and egress from any critical facility must be protected to the 500-year flood elevation. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 5(G), 7-9-12) Secs. 9-63—9-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - VARIANCE PROCEDURES
Sec. 9-81. - Variance procedures. (a) The board of adjustments as established by the City of West Point, Georgia shall hear and decide requests for appeals or variance from the requirements of this chapter. (b) The board shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged an error in any requirement, decision, or determination is made by the building inspector in the enforcement or administration of this chapter. (c) Any person aggrieved by the decision of the board of adjustments may appeal such decision to the Superior Court of Troup or Harris County, as provided in O.C.G.A. § 5-4-1. (d) Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. (e) Variances may be issued for development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use, provided the criteria of this article are met, no reasonable alternative exists, and the development is protected by methods that minimize flood damage during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. (f) Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if ANY increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. (g) In reviewing such requests, the board of adjustments shall consider all technical evaluations, relevant factors, and all standards specified in this and other sections of this chapter. (h) Conditions for variances: (1) A variance shall be issued ONLY when there is: a. A finding of good and sufficient cause, b. A determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship, and; c. A determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisance, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. (2) The provisions of this chapter are minimum standards for flood loss reduction; therefore any deviation from the standards must be weighed carefully. Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief and, in the instance of a historic structure, a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary so as not to destroy the historic character and design of the building. (3) Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice specifying the difference between the base flood elevation and the elevation of the proposed lowest floor and stating that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk to life and property resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. (4) The building inspector shall maintain the records of all appeal actions and report any variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. (i) Upon consideration of the factors listed above and the purposes of this chapter, the board of adjustments may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purposes of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 6, 7-9-12) Secs. 9-82—9-95. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - SEVERABILITY
Sec. 9-96. - Severability. If any section, clause, sentence, or phrase of this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way effect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2012-4, art. 7, 7-9-12)

div.head: Chapter 10 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Nuisances, Ch. 11; offenses, Ch. 12; traffic, Ch. 20. State Law reference— Establishment and jurisdiction of municipal courts, Ga. Const. art. 6, sec. 1, par. 1; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.
Sec. 10-1. - Office of municipal court judge. The offices of municipal court judge and associate municipal court judge of the city are hereby created. The municipal court judge and associate municipal judge shall be elected by the city council. The municipal court shall hear and decide all cases of prosecution for violating the penal laws and ordinances of the city. Sec. 10-2. - Associate municipal court judge to preside in absence of municipal court judge. In case of the absence or disqualification of the municipal court judge, the associate municipal court judge shall perform the duties of the municipal court judge. Sec. 10-3. - Duties of municipal court judge. In addition to hearing all prosecutions for violations of this Code and the laws and ordinances of the city, the municipal court judge shall: (1) Compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of necessary papers; (2) Issue all processes and writs necessary to the exercise of his jurisdiction; (3) Punish contempt by fines not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00) or imprisonment not to exceed (10) days or both; (4) Appoint such special officers as may be necessary, in the absence of the marshal, to execute its writs and processes; (5) Prescribe rules or practices in cases where there are no rules applicable; (6) Bind over or commit to jail offenders against any criminal law of this state, whenever in the course of investigation before such court a proper case therefor shall be made by the evidence. Sec. 10-4. - Superior court rules. The practice in the municipal court shall be governed by the rules of the superior court as far as practicable. Sec. 10-5. - Clerk. A clerk of the municipal court shall be appointed by the city council and shall be responsible for the collection of all fines and forfeitures under order of the municipal court. Sec. 10-6. - Records. (a) The clerk of the municipal court shall keep a criminal docket whereon he shall docket all cases of persons charged with violation of the city ordinances or state statutes, the time of docketing the same, the offense charged, the name of the arresting officer, the final judgment and sentence and other entries to show the progress of the case and its final disposition. (b) The clerk of the municipal court shall also keep the other books and records of the municipal court. (c) The clerk shall be responsible for maintenance of preadjudication documents, maintenance of the court docket, preparation of the court calendar, administering the court while in session at the direction of the municipal court judge, maintenance of all financial records of the municipal court including preparation of bank deposits, reporting dispositions of adjudicated cases to the appropriate agency, forwarding of adjudicated arrests and booking reports to the chief of police, transmitting adjudicated traffic citations and driver's licenses to the department of public safety and forwarding a copy of traffic citations to the chief of police for filing. Sec. 10-7. - Limitations. A prosecution for a violation of a city ordinance shall be commenced within two (2) years after the violation, and any offense against the ordinance for which no prosecution is begun within two (2) years after its commission shall be barred, unless the accused shall have been beyond the limits of the city, in which case the time of absence from the city shall not be embraced or computed as within the two (2) years. Sec. 10-8. - Continuance—On behalf of the defendant. Continuances, except at the instance of the city, shall be granted under the sound discretion of the municipal court. Sec. 10-9. - Same—On behalf of city. The city shall have a right to a continuance only one (1) time in a case, and then only for a good cause. If the accused is in custody, a continuance shall not be for a longer time than three (3) days, except by agreement of the defendant. If the defendant is not in custody, a continuance may be for such time as the court may determine. Sec. 10-10. - Defendant's rights generally. Any person charged with an offense against any ordinance of city shall be informed by summons in writing served on him of the nature of the cause of his accusation and the time and place at which he shall appear, if requested shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses on his behalf, shall have a speedy trial before the municipal court judge, shall be confronted with the witnesses against him and have the privilege of cross examination, and shall have the privilege of defending himself, by counsel or by himself or both, as to him shall seem proper. No person shall be condemned, fined or punished without full opportunity of being heard in his own defense and without having the opportunity of employing counsel, and no person shall be incarcerated in the city jail for more than seventy-two (72) hours without being tried in municipal court, except where the accused elects to waive trial at the first session in writing. Sec. 10-11. - Failure to appear. Any person duly summoned or issued a citation to appear before the municipal court who fails, neglects or refuses to appear, without sufficient excuse, may be fined for contempt by the municipal court, and the accused, if to be found in the city, shall be arrested by the police and brought before the municipal court for trial at such time as the municipal court judge may designate. Sec. 10-12. - Arrest—Generally. The arresting officer, instead of summoning any person charged with violating any city ordinance, may, in his discretion, arrest the accused, releasing him upon his giving bond as provided in this chapter. The person arrested shall be notified of the charge against him and the time and place of his appearance and shall be entitled upon demand to a written statement of the charges against him and have compulsory process to obtain his witnesses. Sec. 10-13. - Same—Warrants. Except as otherwise provided by law, warrants for offenders against the ordinances of the city and the affidavits to obtain the same may be issued by the municipal court judge and shall be directed to the police of the city, or to the sheriff of the county or his deputies. The affidavit and warrant shall be substantially in the form of affidavits and warrants of offenders against the laws of the state, substituting for "Troup County" the words "City of West Point." The officer will execute the warrant placed in his hands, and the arresting officer shall exercise reasonable diligence in bringing the person arrested before the municipal court. Sec. 10-14. - Proceeding against corporation. Whenever complaint is made, under oath, that a corporation has violated any ordinance of this city, it shall be the duty of the officer to whom the complaint was made, having authority to issue warrants for violation of city ordinances, to issue a summons directed to the corporation, requiring it to appear by agent or attorney at the municipal court, at a time therein named, to answer the charge. Service in such cases may be made by delivering a copy of the affidavit of complaint and of the summons to any agent or employee of the defendant, at least three (3) days before the time set for the hearing. Any police officer being competent to make such service, the entry of the arresting officer of the city or affidavit of any other person shall be evidence of such service. The trial may proceed ex parte, if the defendant fails to appear. If judgment is against the defendant, it shall be for a fine and costs, the same to be collected by execution. Sec. 10-15. - Admitting to bail—Initially. Any person arrested by a city officer may give the arresting officer a bond with good security, resident of this city, approved by the chief of police or municipal court judge. Sec. 10-16. - Same—Rearrest. When from any cause the municipal court judge deems it necessary to take the defendant into custody in order to secure the attendance of a defendant out on bond at the trial, he shall issue his warrant for the rearrest of the defendant, except as otherwise provided by law, and shall commit the defendant to jail or require new bond, as the necessities of the case may demand. Sec. 10-17. - Appearance bond forfeiture. (a) Generally. Upon failure of any party or witness or other person who is under bond to appear, such bond shall be forfeited, unless legal excuse is offered in his behalf. The duties in such case that would apply in the superior court to the district attorney, clerk and sheriff shall be performed by the city attorney, clerk of the municipal court and chief of police respectively. (b) Special bail, rule to show cause. All bonds taken under this chapter and bonds given for appearance to abide the sentence of the court shall be special bail, and the power of the surety over the principal in any such bond shall be the same as in any special bail. Upon the failure to appear of any principal in any such bond or recognizance, the municipal court judge shall pass a rule requiring the principal and sureties on such bond to show cause on any day therein named, not to be less than ten (10) days from the passage of such rule, why they should not be required to pay the amount of such bond. This subsection does not apply to cash bonds. (c) Service to rule. A copy of such rule shall be served upon the principal and surety, if to be found in the city, by any officer or member of the police force at least five (5) days before the time therein set for hearing. (d) Judgment on failure to show cause. If no sufficient cause is shown, the municipal court judge shall proceed to enter judgment against such principal and surety for the amount of the bond. Execution shall be issued for the amount of such judgment and placed in the hands of the chief of police, who shall proceed to collect the same by levy and sale as in the case of tax executions; provided, however, judgment shall not be entered against either principal or surety until service shall have been perfected on either the principal or the surety. (e) Issuance and service of scire facias. The clerk of the municipal court shall issue a scire facias on all forfeited bonds and recognizances, whether the same were for appearance before the municipal court or the city council, returnable to regular session of the municipal court against the principal and his sureties, which shall be served by any police officer at least ten (10) days before the return date, or, if the party resides out of the city, scire facias may be served by the publication of the same one (1) time in a public newspaper in the city at least ten (10) days before the return date. The official return of the police officer as to the service of the scire facias shall be sufficient evidence of such service. (f) Entry of judgment. If at the regular session of the municipal court to which the scire facias is returnable no sufficient cause is shown to the contrary, judgment on motion shall be entered against such principal and sureties or such of them as have been served. (g) Collection of judgment. Such judgments so rendered shall be a lien on the property of the defendant from the date of rendition and shall be enforced by execution to be issued by the city clerk, which may be levied and sales made thereunder as other executions. (h) Surrender of principal. The bondsmen may surrender their principal at any time prior to the rendition of judgment on the scire facias issued by the clerk. Such surrender shall release the bondsmen except as to the cost accruing up to the time of such surrender. (i) Not to abate proceedings. Forfeiture of bond shall not abate the proceedings against the defendant, and he may be rearrested and proceeded against for the offense committed. Sec. 10-18. - Costs. The costs taxed against the defendant and his sureties shall be in the same sums as the costs allowed officers of the magistrate court in criminal cases, which shall be paid into the city treasury. Sec. 10-19. - Nonpayment of fines and costs—Confinement. The officer in attendance on the municipal court shall take all persons who have been convicted by the court into his custody. In case such offender is financially able to do so and shall fail to pay the fine and costs immediately upon conviction, such officer shall confine such offender in the city jail until all fines and costs are paid, or shall execute the sentence of the court, whatever it may be. Sec. 10-20. - Same—Execution. (a) On failure of any person on whom a fine is imposed to pay the same immediately, where he is financially able to do so, execution may issue to collect the same, although such person is imprisoned in default of paying such fine. (b) The execution may issue instanter, to be levied upon the goods, chattels, lands and tenements of the person fined, which execution shall bear teste in the name of the mayor, be signed officially by the clerk and be directed to the chief of police. Sec. 10-21. - Prosecuting attorney. The city council may appoint a prosecuting attorney of the municipal court who shall have the duties and authorities as outlined in Georgia law to represent the city in municipal court. Such individual shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the appellate courts of this state. The prosecuting attorney shall serve on a part-time basis, and will be otherwise allowed to engage in the private practice of law. The part-time prosecuting attorney shall serve at the pleasure of the city council, and the city council shall also be authorized to appoint such substitute prosecuting attorneys as may be in the best interests of the city. Nothing herein shall prohibit the city attorney from prosecuting ordinance violations in municipal court or otherwise representing the interests of the city in municipal court or appeals therefrom. (Ord. No. 12-07, § 1, 12-10-12)

div.head: Chapter 11 - NUISANCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Animals and fowl, Ch. 4; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; business regulations, Ch. 6; offenses, Ch. 12; sewerage, Ch. 13; solid waste management, Ch. 16; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 17. State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 11-1. - Rubbish, dangerous walls, debris from burned building, smoke and noxious odors, etc., declared nuisance. (a) It shall be a nuisance per se for an owner of a lot that is vacant or that is not being used for the purpose of producing revenue to allow to remain on the premises piles of rubbish, partially burned timbers of a burned building, or unsightly and dangerous brick walls and it is a nuisance per se for the owner of any such lot to allow the debris from a burned building to remain on the premises, if in doing so water stands about the rubbish, the drainage not being such as to carry the water away speedily. (b) Anyone operating a boiler, furnace or other installation for the combustion of fuel for commercial purposes in the city shall provide an exit for the smoke or any noxious odors or fumes from the installation at an elevation of at least six (6) feet above the height of any building or structure within a radius of three hundred (300) feet. Any such installation operated in violation of this section shall be a nuisance per se and each day's continuance of the operation shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1967, § 16-6) Secs. 11-2—11-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-09, adopted Dec. 13, 2010, repealed former Art. II, §§ 11-26—11-35, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. Former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967, §§ 2-58—2-67 and Ord. of 8-12-02(1).
Sec. 11-26. - Complaint to be filed with clerk-treasurer. If a public nuisance within the city be complained of by any person having the legal right so to complain, such complainant shall file with the city clerk-treasurer a written complaint against such nuisance and the person maintaining same. Such complaint must plainly, fully and distinctly set forth the nature of the nuisance, where located and by whom maintained, the latter party being designated as the respondent. If no private citizen is specially injured by a public nuisance such complaint may be filed by the city attorney on behalf of the public. (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-10) Sec. 11-27. - Nuisance defined generally; public nuisance defined. (a) A nuisance is anything that causes hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable man. (O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1). (b) Nuisances are either public or private. A public nuisance is one which damages all persons who come within the sphere of its operation, though it may vary in its effects on individuals. A private nuisance is one limited in its injurious effects to one (1) or a few individuals. (O.C.G.A § 41-1-2). (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-10) Sec. 11-28. - Presentation of complaint to public officer/building officer; issuance of complaint. After a complaint authorized by this article has been filed with the clerk-treasurer, the clerk-treasurer shall deliver a copy of such complaint to the public officer or building officer, is a different person. The public officer/building officer shall forthwith make an investigation of the alleged public nuisance. If the officer's investigation identifies the possible existence of a public nuisance, the public officer may issue a complaint against the respondent and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the respondent according to section 11-28 hereof. The complaint shall state the nature of the alleged nuisance, the street address and official tax map reference of the property whereupon the nuisance is alleged to exist, identify the person by whom the alleged nuisance is maintained; and contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance. The summons shall notify the respondent that a hearing will be held before a court of competent jurisdiction as determined by O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5, at a date and time certain and at a place within the county or municipality where the alleged nuisance is located. (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-10) Sec. 11-29. - Service of summons and complaint. A true and correct copy of the summons and complaint shall be served on said respondent by the public officer or building officer. Such service shall be perfected in the same manner as copies of common law suits and process thereto attached are served in the superior courts of the state. If notice cannot be personally served upon the respondent or if the respondent resides outside the city, service shall be perfected by publication in the manner in which service is perfected by publication in the superior courts of the state. (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-10) Sec. 11-30. - Hearing. (a) Such hearing shall be held not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than forty-five (45) days after notice to the respondent. The respondent shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing. (b) The court shall, after notice to the respondent, on the date set hearing of such complaint, or at such subsequent date to which the hearing may be continued by the court, hear the case, and during such hearing or trial each party to the case shall have the right to offer any competent and relevant evidence on the issues involved. (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-10) Sec. 11-31. - Order of abatement. If, after such notice and hearing, the court determines that a public nuisance exists, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the respondent an order to abate such nuisance. (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-10) Sec. 11-32. - Abatement by city; collection of costs. If the respondent fails to abate such nuisance within the time specified in such order, then the court shall cause an order to be issued, signed by the municipal court judge and directed to the chief of police, requiring such officer to abate the nuisance complained of, and such officer is authorized to employ such help in abating the nuisance as may be necessary and reasonable. The reasonable cost of the abatement of such nuisance shall be paid by the respondent, and, if the respondent shall fail or refuse to pay same, it shall be the duty of the city clerk-treasurer to issue an execution for such cost of the abatement in the form authorized by law against the respondent, which shall be delivered over to the chief of police, to be executed by such officer for the purpose of satisfying the amount of same and such additional legal cost as may accrue on same. (Ord. No. 2010-09, 12-13-2010) Sec. 11-33. - Abatement of bawdy house. On complaint in writing, under oath, being made by any officer or citizen of the city to the municipal court judge alleging that a certain person, naming him, is guilty of a public nuisance by keeping a bawdy house in the city, describing the house, and that such nuisance should be abated, the municipal court judge shall appoint a day for hearing such complaint or charge and shall issue his warrant against such person complained of, commanding the chief of police or any police officer to arrest and have such person before the municipal court judge on the day appointed to answer the complaint. If it shall be proven on such trial that a prostitute, or a woman of ill fame, resides in the house with the person charged, or is in the habit of visiting said house, and the house is at the same time visited by men who do not reside in it, this shall be prima facie evidence of the truth of the charge. If upon trial the defendants be found guilty of the charge, it shall be the duty of the municipal court judge to render judgment against the defendants that they are guilty as charged and for all the costs of the whole proceeding and to make an order requiring the defendants within forty-eight (48) hours to abate such nuisance and abandon the house. If the defendants shall fail or refuse to abate the nuisance or vacate the house, at the expiration of such forty-eight (48) hours, it shall be the duty of the municipal court judge to make an order requiring the chief of police to put the defendants and their property out of the house and the chief of police must forthwith execute such order. Secs. 11-34—11-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MOSQUITO CONTROL
Sec. 11-56. - Standing water and high grass prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit within the corporate limits of the city any collection of standing water or flowing water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed (unless such collection of water is treated so as to effectually prevent such breeding) or any high grass, shrubbery or weeds in which mosquitoes might harbor or shelter. (b) Collections of water prohibited by this section shall include those contained in ditches, pools, ponds, cisterns, tanks, shallow wells, barrels, troughs (except horse or watering troughs in frequent use), urns, cans, boxes, bottles, tubs, buckets, defective house-roof gutters, tanks or flush toilets or other similar water containers. (Code 1967, § 13-43) Sec. 11-57. - Methods of treating to prevent mosquito breeding. The methods of treatment of any collection of water prohibited by this article shall be approved by the accredited health officer and may be one (1) or more of the following: (1) Screening with wire netting of at least sixteen (16) meshes to the inch each way, or with any other material that will prevent the ingress and egress of mosquitoes. (2) Complete emptying every seven (7) days of unscreened containers, together with their thorough drying and cleaning. (3) Using a larvicide approved and applied under the direction of the health officer. (4) Covering completely the surface of the water with kerosene, petroleum or paraffin oil once in seven (7) days. (5) Cleaning and keeping sufficiently free of vegetation and other obstructions and stocking with mosquito destroying fish. (6) Filling and draining to the satisfaction of the health officer or his accredited representative. (7) Proper disposal by removal and destruction of tin cans, boxes, broken or empty bottles and similar articles likely to hold water. (Code 1967, § 13-44) Sec. 11-58. - Treatment by city. Should the person responsible for conditions giving rise to the breeding or harboring of mosquitoes fail or refuse to take necessary measures to prevent the same within twenty-four (24) hours after due notice has been given to him, the health officer, or his authorized agent, is hereby authorized to do so and all necessary costs incurred by him shall be a charge against the property owner or other person offending, as the case may be. (Code 1967, § 13-45) Sec. 11-59. - Authority of health officer. For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article, the health officer, or his accredited agent under his authority, may at all reasonable times enter in and upon any premises within his jurisdiction. Any person charged with any of the duties imposed by this article failing within the time designated by this article, or within the time stated in the notice of the health officer as the case may be, to perform or to carry out the measures necessary to the satisfaction of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 of this Code. Each day after the expiration of the aforesaid time that said person fails to comply with this article shall constitute a separate violation of this article. (Code 1967, § 13-46) Secs. 11-60—11-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - NOISE
Secs. 11-81—11-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - WEEDS
Sec. 11-101. - Definition. As used in this article, the term "weeds" shall mean and include grass, weeds, bushes, poison ivy, poison oak or any other vegetation, except trees, ornamental shrubbery, flowers and garden vegetables. (Code 1967, § 11-16) Sec. 11-102. - Prohibited. It shall be unlawful and constitute a nuisance for any person to permit weeds to grow to a height in excess of one (1) foot on any premises or vacant lot owned or occupied by him within the city. (Code 1967, § 11-17) Sec. 11-103. - Notice to cut. (a) Whenever weeds are found growing on any premises or vacant lot within the city to a height in excess of one (1) foot, the code enforcement officer shall give notice, in writing, to the owner or occupant thereof that such weeds must be cut within ten (10) days from the date of service of the notice. (b) The service of the notice provided for in this section shall be made as follows: (1) When the owner is a resident of the city, by personal service. (2) When the owner is not a resident of the city, by personal service upon the occupant of the property. (3) When the property is vacant and the owner does not reside within the city, by posting the notice on the property. (c) Any owner or occupant who fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the terms of a notice served pursuant to this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Code 1967, § 11-18) Sec. 11-104. - Cutting by city. If an owner or occupant fails to comply with a notice served pursuant to this article, the city may cut, or cause to be cut, the weeds and shall charge the cost of same against the owner or occupant and such cost shall be a lien on the property to be collected as other debts are collected on liens enforced. (Code 1967, § 11-19) Sec. 11-105. - Tracts of five acres or more. All tracts of land within the city which equal or exceed five (5) acres, and all contiguous vacant lots the combined area of which shall equal or exceed five (5) acres, shall be kept cut and maintained for a distance of one hundred (100) feet from the points where such tract or tracts borders any inhabited or improved property and fifty (50) feet from any dedicated street right-of-way. (Code 1967, § 11-20) Sec. 11-106. - Remedies cumulative. The remedies provided for in this article shall be considered as cumulative of the remedies now provided by law for the abatement of nuisances and not in exclusion thereof. (Code 1967, § 11-21)

div.head: Chapter 12 - OFFENSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Animals and fowl, Ch. 4; cemeteries, Ch. 7; municipal court, Ch. 10; nuisances, Ch. 11; traffic, Ch. 20. State Law reference— Limitations on home rule powers of municipal corporations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.
Sec. 12-1. - Advertising, circulars, handbills, etc.—Attaching to structures, placing in vehicles or on private premises without consent. It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, paint, or place upon any bridge or any lamppost or corner post or utility post or on any building or any fence or in or on any vehicle or to distribute or throw on any private porch, yard, lawn, steps, driveway, or on any vacant property in the city, without the express written consent of the owner thereof, any unsolicited handbills, circulars, cards, posters, dodgers, pamphlets, booklets, brochures, or advertising samples. Sec. 12-2. - Same—Distributing on streets. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute commercial handbills, circulars, cards, posters, pamphlets, brochures, or booklets on the portion of public streets used for vehicular traffic. Sec. 12-3. - Soliciting alms. It shall be unlawful for any person to ask, beg, or solicit alms in the city from any person or any business whatsoever, unless a permit is first obtained from the chief of police. Sec. 12-4. - Conspiracy. It shall be unlawful for any two (2) or more persons and each of them to conspire to do any act contrary to the ordinances of this city. They may be jointly or severally prosecuted. Sec. 12-5. - Disorderly conduct. (a) Any person shall be guilty of disorderly conduct if he: (1) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of safety or his life, limb or health; (2) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby public property or property of any other person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; (3) Endangers lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats and abusive conduct; (4) Causes, provokes, or engages in any fight, brawl, or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health, or property of another or public property; (5) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking, or engaging in any fight or brawl; (6) Jostles or roughly crowds or pushes any person in any public place; (7) Collects in bodies or crowds for unlawful purposes; (8) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of or with the intent to engage in gaming; (9) Frequents any public place with intent to obtain money from another by any illegal and fraudulent scheme, trick, artifice or device; (10) Assembles with another or others for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city or aids or abets therein; (11) Utters, while in a state of anger, in the presence of another, any lewd or obscene words or epithets; (12) Frequents any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs are practiced, allowed or tolerated; (13) Acts in a dangerous manner toward others; (14) Uses "fighting words" directed towards any person who becomes outraged and thus creates turmoil; (15) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of doing bodily harm to another; (16) By acts of violence, interferes with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; (17) Congregates with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt or impede the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when ordered to do so by a peace officer or other person having authority; (18) Makes any unreasonably loud of unnecessary noise; (19) Damages, befouls or disturbs public property or the property of another so as to create a hazardous, unhealthy or physically offensive condition; (20) Willfully makes, continues or causes to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary, unusual or excessive noise between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time in a residential area which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of a normal sensitiveness residing in the area; (21) Makes or allows to be emitted from the radio or stereo system from any vehicle any excessive noise, loud music or loud sounds likely to annoy the senses of the average person; (22) Without provocation, uses to or of another person in such other person's presence, opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in such other person's presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words"; or (23) Without provocation, uses obscene and vulgar or profane language in the presence of or by telephone to a person under the age of fourteen (14) years which threatens an immediate breach of the peace. (b) Any person who commits the offense of disorderly conduct shall be quilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. of 6-11-90; Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) Sec. 12-6. - Disturbing divine worship. It shall be unlawful for any person to be engaged in loud talking or laughing, or any other disorderly conduct in or near the entrance or vestibule of any church or other place of worship during divine service or to congregate in and around any such place and behave in such a rude and disorderly manner as to become offensive to persons attending such service. Sec. 12-7. - Maintaining a disorderly house. A person who keeps and maintains, either by himself or others, a common, ill-governed, and disorderly house, to the encouragement of gaming, drinking, or other misbehavior, or to the common disturbance of the neighborhood or orderly citizens, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, adopted April 9, 2012, amended § 12-7 title to read as herein set out. Former § 12-7 title pertained to disorderly houses. Sec. 12-8. - Fraudulent sales. It shall be unlawful for any person, by advertising by newspapers, radios, posters or otherwise, to represent that he is operating, offering or maintaining "fire sales," "wreck sales," "bankrupt sales," "closing out sales" or "going-out-of-business sales" and similar sales whereby members of the public are led to believe that they are being offered merchandise at reduced rates on account of fires, wrecks, bankruptcies, closing out or discontinuance of business, when in fact sales are not bona fide, but are fakes and frauds, and the advertisements and representations are untrue and false. Sec. 12-9. - Bad checks. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain money, property or credit by check, draft or order when such check, draft or order is not paid by the drawee upon presentation thereof and such check, draft, or order is issued with fraudulent intent. (b) The drawing or issuing of a check, draft, or order and the obtaining of money, property or credit therein without having sufficient money or property with which to pay the same shall be prima facie evidence of fraudulent intent. Sec. 12-10. - Gambling—Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to play or bet for money or other thing of value at any game played with cards, dice or balls or at any other game or device or on any horse race or chicken or other animal fight within the city. Sec. 12-11. - Same—Possessing implements therefor. It shall be unlawful for any person in this city to have in his possession or custody any cards, dice, balls or other gaming implements with the intent to use the same in playing or betting for money or other thing of value. Sec. 12-12. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, adopted April 9, 2012, repealed § 12-12, which pertained to lottery tickets, etc. and derived from the original codification. Sec. 12-13. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, adopted April 9, 2012, repealed § 12-13, which pertained to indecency, obscenity—generally and derived from the original codification. Sec. 12-14. - Indecency, obscenity—In dress; pictures; performance. It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any public place naked or in an indecent or lewd dress or to make any indecent exposure of his or her person or be guilty of any indecent or lewd act or behavior or to exhibit or sell or offer for sale any obscene, vulgar or licentious book, picture or painting or to exhibit or perform in a hall, house, or public place any indecent, immoral or lewd play or dance or to sing to a public audience any sacrilegious, indecent, vulgar or lewd song. Sec. 12-15. - Prostitution. Prostitution, as defined by state law, shall be unlawful in the city. Sec. 12-16. - Maximum length of knives. It shall be unlawful for any person to have on his person any knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three (3) inches, unless the knife is securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for harmful use. This shall include butcher knives or any other knife which does not close and shall include straight razors and ice picks. Such prohibition shall not apply within the person's own home, on his premises or on the premises of the parent or the guardian of the person. The provision as to ice picks shall not apply to any person who is delivering ice within the city while he is making such deliveries. Sec. 12-17. - Switchblade knife—Possession by minor. (a) It shall be unlawful for any minor to be in possession of any switchblade knife or any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle or any knife with any other obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, unless such minor is upon the premises of his home or upon the premises of his parent or guardian. (b) It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly permit his minor child to be in possession of a switchblade knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle or any knife with any other obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, unless such minor is upon the premises of his home or upon the premises of his parent or guardian. Sec. 12-18. - Same—Sale to minor. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell to any minor a switchblade knife or any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle or any knife with any other obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open. If a knife as described above is sold to a minor, it shall be presumed that the seller had knowledge of the fact that the person was a minor. Sec. 12-19. - Police officers generally. (a) Resisting, obstructing, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to resist, obstruct or oppose any police officer in making or attempting to make a legal arrest of any person or in serving or attempting to serve any legal process or order issued by the authorities of the city, county or state. (b) Authority to summon aid; compliance. Any police officer of the city shall have the power to summon to his aid any number of citizens, if any person shall resist his authority or attempt to escape custody or to avoid an arrest, and it shall be unlawful for any person so summoned to refuse to obey the call of such police officer or give the assistance required. It shall be unlawful for any person summoned by any police officer to aid in suppressing an affray, riot, breach of the peace or other outrage to refuse to do so or to refuse when summoned as aforesaid to aid in arresting any offender. (c) Escape; attempted escape. It shall be unlawful for any person to escape or attempt to escape from any city police officer or from the city jail, city vehicle, or from any other person in charge of a work gang. (d) Impersonating police officer. It shall be unlawful for any person to appear on the streets wearing clothes or uniforms or badges which closely resemble the uniforms or badges adopted by the police force or to do any other similar act or to, in any way, impersonate a police officer. (e) Failure to obey a police officer. It shall be unlawful for any person refuse to obey any lawful order, request or demand of any police officer, while performing his lawful duties. (f) Unlawful fleeing from a police officer. It shall be unlawful for any person to flee from a police officer, who has a lawful reason to confront approach or detain this person. It shall prim facial evidence that the confrontation was lawful if the person continues or refuse to obey any lawful order, request or demand of any police officer, to stop his flight. (g) Obstructing or hindering law enforcement officers. Whoever knowingly and willfully resists, obstructs, or opposes any law enforcement officer, prison guard, correctional officer, probation supervisor, parole supervisor, or conservation ranger in the lawful discharge of his official duties by offering or doing violence to the person of such officer or legally authorized person is guilty of a felony and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by imprisonment for not less than one (1) nor more than five (5) years. (Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) Sec. 12-20. - Property damage. (a) Street and traffic signs. No person shall remove or mutilate, deface, destroy or injure any street identification or traffic-control sign, signal, marker or device. (b) Utility poles, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to cut or in any way deface any telegraph, telephone, electric light or other public utility pole or to break any lamp or insulator or to throw any missile at any wire or in way or manner interfere with any pole, line or lamp of any electric light, telegraph, telephone or other public utility to the injury of any such property. (c) Buildings, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, draw, carve, or cut any letter, word or device or in any way mutilate or deface any church, bridge, public or private building or its appurtenances or any statue, tombstone, gravestone, marker or memorial that may be erected in the city or any wall or fence belonging to another. (d) Trees. It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, injure or destroy any shade tree on the sidewalks, streets or public areas in the city, except as may be required by the city. (e) Disturbing survey monument or marker. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or disturb in any manner the stone monuments or iron markers used in the survey of the city and to be used in the future for future reference points without consent of the city council. Sec. 12-21. - Discharging airguns, crossbows, etc. It is unlawful for any person to discharge any airgun or air pistol or any similar device or any longbow, crossbow, or any other type of bow designed to discharge arrows in or onto any of the streets, sidewalks, alleyways, or other public property in the city or in any of the lots or properties thereof unless permission for the discharge of such devices has been given to the person discharging same by the owner of the property on which the devices are discharged and unless the discharging of same is so controlled that no pellet, shot, arrow or any matter so discharged shall cross the property line of the person granting such permission. Sec. 12-22. - Firing guns, pistols, other firearms. It shall be unlawful to discharge or fire any gun, pistol, or other firearm of any type within the city, provided this section shall not apply to gun clubs or military companies upon such part of the city as may be set apart and designated for the use of such guns clubs or military companies or to law enforcement officers in the discharge of their duties. Sec. 12-23. - Possession of firearm by minor. It shall be unlawful for any minor to be in possession of any firearm while not under the direct supervision of his parent or guardian. Sec. 12-24. - Slaughtering animals; curing hides. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or operate any abattoir or butcher pen or slaughter barn inside the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to cure hides in the city. Sec. 12-25. - Public drunkenness. It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear within the corporate limits of the city: (1) In an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own unless by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which intoxicated condition is exhibited or may be manifest by boisterousness or by an indecent condition or act or by stupor or a deep sleep or by impairment of ambulation or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language. For the purposes of this section, public place shall mean any place where the conduct so exhibited or manifested may reasonably be expected to be viewed by persons other than members of the actor's family or household; (2) Consume alcoholic beverages on any public street, sidewalk or any other public property within the corporate limits of the city. Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages or containers with the seal-broken shall be prima facie evidence of consumption; (3) Consume alcoholic beverages in a vehicle on or not on any public or private parking lot within the corporate limits of the city. Possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages or containers with the seal broken shall be prima facie evidence of consumption, it shall be unlawful for any person to consume while in public any alcoholic beverage unless the original container is concealed from view, except those maintained at establishments holding a valid on-premises license for the retail sale of beer or wine. (Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) State Law reference— Restriction on enforcement of local ordinances relating to drinking, being a common drunkard, or being found in an intoxicated condition, OC.G.A. § 37-8-11. O.C.G.A. § 16-13-2 (2011), conditional discharge for possession of controlled substances as first offense and certain nonviolent property crimes; dismissal of charges; restitution to victims. Sec. 12-26. - Open containers of alcoholic beverages, consuming alcoholic beverages in motor vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages or to have in possession any open container or package of alcoholic beverages while aboard any motor vehicle operated or parked on any public street or public property or on any private property open to public access or vehicular traffic unless such person is a passenger in a motor vehicle driven by a hired chauffeur or other driver which is licensed by the city or state to operate a motor vehicle for hire or is a passenger aboard a chartered carrier or a carrier wherein the possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages is allowed by law and unless such open container or package is in the trunk of the motor vehicle or kept in a locked glove compartment or in some other area of the vehicle not normally occupied by the driver or passenger. A container or package shall not be deemed open when the original seal is unbroken, and any receptacle with an open top or with a straw shall be classified as an open container or package. Sec. 12-27. - Unauthorized accumulation of vehicles in a broken-down condition or without a license plate. (a) The unauthorized accumulation of one (1) or more vehicles, or any major part thereof, which does not have a current license plate or which are in any one (1) of the following conditions: (1) Resting on blocks; (2) Without wheels; (3) With major parts missing; (4) Without tires; (5) In a state of repair which precludes further use; (6) Remain motionless for an unreasonable period of time shall be declared unlawful, except where vehicles are stored in an enclosed building or located on the premises of licensed business enterprise operated in a lawful place or manner when necessary to the operation of such licensed business enterprise; provided, however, where any such motor vehicles, or a major part thereof, are not located in an enclosed building, such premises shall be screened on all sides by fence or shrubbery so as to shield such accumulation from sight; (7) A vehicle lacking a current, valid Georgia tag shall be considerable inoperable for the purposes of this section; (8) For the purposes of this section, either the owner of the real property upon which such vehicle is situated, or the lawful possessor in control of said real property, or both, may be held liable for violation of this section. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to discard and abandon on the streets of the city any broken-down vehicles. Such vehicles shall be properly disposed of by taking to a junkyard or other suitable place, and shall not be abandoned on the streets of the city. (c) Derelict motor vehicles; determination of status; disposition; violations and penalties.
