After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been given tentative approval by the municipal planning board, the subdivider may, within one (1) year from tentative approval, submit to the municipal planning board the following: (1) A letter requesting review and approval, of a final plat and giving the name and address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the municipal planning board on the final plat shall be sent; (2) Five (5) copies of the final plat and other documents, as specified in section 18-36, the original and at least one (1) mylar copy. (3) A final plat filing fee as provided in the City of West Point fee schedule. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-57. - Review; notice of hearing; effect of nonaction. (a) The director of the planning department shall check the final plat for conformance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat and with the rules and regulations of this chapter and report his findings and recommendations to the mayor and council at the next scheduled meeting. (b) The mayor and council shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original tracing and two (2) prints of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. If action on a final plat is not taken by the mayor and council within thirty (30) days of the date of the submittal, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-58. - Recording. (a) Upon approval of a final plat, the director of planning shall have the final plat recorded in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Troup or Harris County. The subdivider shall be responsible for the payment of the recording fee at the time of submitting the final plat as provided in section 18-57. (b) Upon recording of the approved final plat, the original tracing or a reproducible linen print of the final plat with all certificates endorsed thereon shall be provided by the subdivider for the records of the City of West Point. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-59. - Specifications. The final plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the preliminary plat and shall be clearly and legibly drawn in permanent ink on tracing cloth. Sheet sizes shall be a minimum of eighteen (18) inches by twenty-four (24) inches, and where more than one (1) sheet is required an index map shall be required on the same size sheet. It shall show the following: (1) Bearings and distances to the nearest existing street lines or benchmarks or other permanent monuments (not less than three (3)) shall be accurately described on the plat; (2) Municipal, county and land-lot lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles when such lines traverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision; (3) Exact boundary lines of the tract, determined by a field survey, giving distances to the nearest one-tenth ( 1/10 ) foot and angles to the nearest minute, which shall be balanced and dosed with an error of closure not to exceed one (1) to five thousand (5,000); (4) Name of subdivision, exact locations, widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat; (5) Street centerlines showing angles of deflection, angles, of intersection, radii, and lengths of tangents; (6) Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-tenth ( 1/10 ) foot and bearings; (7) Lots numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically; (8) Location, dimensions, and purposes of any easements and any areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use; (9) Accurate location, material, and description of monuments and markers; (10) A statement, either directly on the plat or in an identified attached document, of any private covenants; (11) The following certifications: a. An engineer's or surveyor's certification, directly on the final plat as follows: "It is hereby certified that this plat is true and correct and was prepared from an actual survey of the property by me or under my supervision; that all monuments shown hereon actually exist or are marked as "Future," and their location, size, type and material are correctly shown; and that all engineering requirements of the Land Subdivision Ordinance of the City of West Point, Georgia, have been fully complied with.
b. Certificate of ownership, dedication and taxes paid: "I (we) hereby certify that I am (we are) the owner(s) of the property shown and described hereon and that I (we) hereby adopt this plan of subdivision with my (our) free consent, establish the minimum building restriction lines, dedicate all streets, alleys, walks, parks, and other open spaces to public or private use as noted, and grant easements as shown on the plat. I (we) also certify that all current state, city and county taxes or other assessments have been paid.
c. Copy of official action of governing body. A copy of the ordinance or resolution adopted by the governing body accepting the streets, easements and any other property dedicated by the owner for public use, as indicated on the final plat, shall be attached to the final plat before recording. d. A certificate of approval of the final plat by the City of West Point, directly on the plat, as follows: "Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Ordinance of the City of West Point, Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this Final Plat was given Final Approval by the Mayor and Council on ________, 20___.
(Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Secs. 18-60—18-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN REQUIREMENTS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A), set out provisions intended for use as art. W. For purposes to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as art. IV.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 18-81. - Suitability of land. Land subject to flooding, improper drainage, or erosion or that is, for, topographical or other reasons, unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use nor for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety, or property unless the hazards can be and are corrected. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-82. - Name of subdivision. The name of the subdivision must have the approval of the municipal planning board. The name shall-not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of an existing subdivision. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-83. - Access. Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a public street. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-84. - Conformance to major streets and other plans. (a) All streets and other features of the major street plan of the city shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and the dimension indicated on the major street plan adopted by the municipal planning board. (b) When features of other plans adopted by the municipal planning board, such as schools or other public building sites, parks; or other land for public uses, are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall be either dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition within a reasonable time by the appropriate public agency. (c) Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to public use that the municipal planning board finds not required or suitable for such public use, the municipal planning board shall refuse to approve the plat and shall notify, the governing body of the reasons for such action. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-85. - Large-scale developments. The requirements of this chapter may be modified in the case of a large-scale community or neighborhood unit, such as a housing project or shopping center which is not subdivided into customary lots, blocks, and streets, if the development is approved by the municipal planning board and if it is in conformity with the purpose and intent of this chapter. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-86. - Required improvements, utilities. (a) Every subdivider shall be required to have installed by the appropriate city agency at his expense, with approval of the agency concerned, the following street improvements and utilities: (1) Except on major or limited-access streets, street grading, curbs and street paving; (2) Sanitary sewer lines and manholes, storm-drainage facilities, sidewalks (when determined by the municipal planning board to be essential for the safety of pedestrians) and monuments and markers; (3) If the required sewer line cannot be connected to a trunkline sewer at the time of the development of the subdivision, septic tanks shall be installed by and at the expense of the subdivider or lot purchaser for interim use, in conformity with the requirements of the county health department; (4) Water mains within the subdivision with connections to each lot. (b) All required street improvements, utilities and monuments shall be built to standards specified by the agency responsible for each. All utilities to be installed in the streets shall be placed and compacted prior to paving. (c) The subdivider shall not be relieved of his responsibility to provide required improvements until the improvements are accepted by the governing body by ordinance or resolution. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Secs. 18-87—18-110. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - STREETS AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY
Sec. 18-111. - Continuation of existing—Streets. Existing streets in a subdivision shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. See illustration 2 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-112. - Street names. Street names in a subdivision shall require the approval of the municipal planning board. Streets that are obviously in alignment with streets already existing and named shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate or closely approximate those of existing streets. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-113. - Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet shall not be permitted in a subdivision. See illustration 3 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-114. - Culs-de-sac. Except where topographic or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable, culs-de-sac or dead-end streets in a subdivision shall not be greater in length than eight hundred (800) feet. They shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having a property line radius of at least fifty (50) feet with an outside payment radius of at least forty (40) feet. See illustration 4 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-115. - Development along major street, limited-access highway or railroad right-of-way. Where a subdivision abuts or contains a major street, a limited-access, highway, or a railroad right-of-way, the municipal planning board may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, either as a marginal access street or, at a distance suitable for an appropriate use of the intervening land, with a nonaccess reservation suitably planted. Due regard should be given requirements for approach grades and future grade, separations in determining distances. Lots shall have no access to a major street or limited-access highway, but only to an access street. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-116. - Alleys. Alleys may be required at the rear of all lots used for multifamily, commercial, or industrial developments but shall not be provided in one- and two-family residential developments unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the municipal planning board of the need for alleys. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-117. - Reserve strips. Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys, and public grounds shall not be permitted in a subdivision unless their control is placed in the hands of the governing body, under conditions approved by the governing body. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-118. - Easements. (a) Easements having a minimum width of five (5) feet and located along the right of way shall be provided in a subdivision, as required for utility lines and underground mains and cables. (b) Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater or drainage right-of-way of adequate width. Parallel streets may be required by the municipal planning board in connection therewith. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-119. - Street right-of-way widths. The right-of-way width in a subdivision shall be the distance across a street from property line to property line. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: (1) Major street widths, as shown on the major street plan; (2) Collector streets, sixty (60) feet; (3) Minor streets and dead-end streets, fifty (50) feet; (4) Alleys, sixteen (16) feet. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-120. - Street pavement widths. Street pavement widths in a subdivision shall be as follows: (1) Collector streets, thirty-two (32) feet; (2) Minor streets and dead-end streets, twenty-four (24) feet. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-121. - Street grades. Maximum and minimum street grades in a subdivision shall be as follows: (1) Major streets, not in excess of seven (7) percent; (2) Collector streets, not in excess of ten (10) percent; (3) Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys, not in excess of fourteen (14) percent; (4) No street grade shall be less than one-half (½) of one (1) percent. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-122. - Horizontal curvature. The minimum radii of centerline curvature on a subdivision street shall be as follows: (1) Major streets, as indicated on the major street plan, but in no case less than eight hundred (800) feet; (2) Collector streets, two hundred (200) feet; (3) Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys, one hundred (100) feet. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-123. - Tangents. Between reverse curves on a subdivision street there shall be a tangent, as depicted on illustration 5 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, having a length not less than the following: (1) Major streets, two hundred (200) feet; (2) Collector streets, one hundred (100) feet. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-124. - Vertical alignment. Vertical alignment of subdivision streets shall be such that the following requirements are met: (1) Major streets shall have a sight distance of at least five hundred (500) feet at six (6) feet above ground level. (2) Collector streets shall have a sight distance of at least two hundred (200) feet at six (6) feet above ground level. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-125. - Street intersections. Street intersections in subdivisions shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall be at an angle of less than sixty (60) degrees, unless required by unusual circumstances. See illustration 6 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Secs. 18-126—18-140. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - BLOCKS AND LOTS
Sec. 18-141. - Block lengths and widths. Block lengths and widths in subdivisions shall be as follows and as depicted in illustration 7 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer: (1) Blocks shall be not greater than one thousand eight hundred (1,800) feet nor less than six hundred (600) feet in length, except in unusual circumstances. (2) Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two (2) tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major streets, limited-access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-142. - Lot sizes. (a) Residential lots in subdivisions shall meet the lot width and lot area requirements of the zoning ordinance. In the absence of a zoning ordinance, residential lots shall be not less than eighty-five (85) feet wide at the building line. (b) Residential lots shall have a depth of not less than eighty-five (85) feet and not greater than two (2) times the width of the lot at the building line, unless unusual circumstances make these limitations not practicable. (c) Where individual septic tanks are used, the health officer shall prescribe minimum lot sizes to conform to health standards. (d) Commercial and industrial lots shall be adequate to provide service areas and off-street parking suitable to use intended. See illustration S on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (e) Residential corner lots shall have adequate width to meet building setback requirements from both abutting streets. See illustration 9 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-143. - Lot lines. All lot lines in a subdivision shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines, unless not practicable because of topographic or other features. See illustration 10 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-144. - Building lines. A building line meeting the front yard setback requirements of the zoning ordinance shall be established on all lots in subdivisions. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-145. - Lots abutting public streets. Each lot in a subdivision shall abut upon a dedicated public street. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A)) Sec. 18-146. - Double and reverse frontage lots. Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation in a subdivision. A planting screen easement of at least ten (10) feet and across which there shall be no right of access shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. See illustration 11 on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. (Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1(App. A))

Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 8; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-2; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; specific business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, adopted Nov. 12, 2012, denominated §§ 19-1—19-6 as Art. I of Ch. 19, titled to read as herein set out.
Sec. 19-1. - Due date for payment of taxes. All taxes due the city shall be payable on and after the first day of October and until the twentieth day of December in each year. The city clerk-treasurer shall publish once, ten (10) days before the time of payment of taxes, a notice thereof in some newspaper circulated in the city. (Code 1967, § 22-11) Sec. 19-2. - Executions for delinquent taxes. After the twentieth day of December in each year the clerk shall issue executions on all assessments upon which taxes have not been paid. (Code 1967, § 22-12) Sec. 19-3. - Rate of taxation to be fixed. Not later than the second Monday in September of each year the city council shall determine the rate of taxation for that year. (Code 1967, § 22-14) Sec. 19-4. - Collection of back taxes. (a) When any property subject to taxation has not been returned for taxation assessed in any year or years prior to the then present year and no taxes paid thereon for such prior year or years, or when any person shall fail to return property within the time prescribed, the tax assessors shall assess a valuation for the year and double tax it. The assessors shall give to the owner notice of the time and place when they will fix such valuation. If the owner is unknown, no notice need be given. Should the amount of such double tax not be paid within five (5) days and application for a release or decrease has not been filed, then execution shall issue therefor, as for other taxes, against the owner of such property, if known, against the particular property. (b) In case returns on assessments have been made for any prior years and no taxes paid and no executions issued thereon, the clerk-treasurer shall give the owner of the property five (5) days' notice that execution will be issued and, if the amount of the taxes thereon is not paid in said five (5) days, then execution shall issue and be collected as provided for other taxes. (Code 1967, § 22-16) Sec. 19-5. - Executions and sales. All executions of the city for taxes shall be made returnable to the second regular meeting of the council after the issuing of the execution. Whenever any property is levied on under any execution issued by authority of the city, it shall be advertised in the same manner and the time, place and method of conducting the sale and making titles shall be the same as sheriff's sales for state and county taxes, except that the officer making the levy may advertise the sale in any one of the newspapers published in the city, and the sale may be conducted by the chief of police; and provided, further, where the property levied on is personalty, the sale shall be advertised by posting a notice at the council chamber door and at two (2) other places in the city ten (10) days before the sale. (Code 1967, § 22-17) Sec. 19-6. - Sales and use tax imposed. A combination of city-county local sales and use tax at the rate of one (1) percent is hereby levied by the city council. (Code 1967, § 22-22) ARTICLE II. - HOTEL/MOTEL AND ACCOMMODATION TAX[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-06, § 2, adopted Nov. 12, 2012, denominated § 19-7 as Art. II of Ch. 19, titled to read as herein set out.
Sec. 19-7. - Hotel-motel and accommodations excise tax. (a) Levied; amount; exception. There is hereby levied an excise tax in the city upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room or rooms, lodging, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business licenses or occupation taxes to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value in the amount of five (5) percent of the charge to the public for the furnishing of such accommodations; provided that such tax shall not be levied upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations for a period of more than ten (10) consecutive days or for use as meeting rooms or upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished for a period of one (1) or more consecutive days for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. (b) Collection; payment. The excise tax levied hereby shall be collected by the person or legal entity furnishing such accommodations at the time the same are furnished and shall be reported to the city quarterly on the first day of January, the first day of April, the first day of July and the first day of October of each year upon forms made available by the clerk-treasurer of the city and payment of the excise tax levied hereby shall be made to the city at the time each quarterly return is filed; provided, however, that the excise tax adopted shall be effective on February 1, 1991, with the first quarterly return and payment to be due on April 1, 1991, as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(12). (c) When due; late penalty. The quarterly return required in O.C.G.A. § 30-5-302 shall be filed and the payment of the excise tax levied hereby shall be due and payable on the first day of each quarter. A penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax due shall be assessed against those persons or legal entities who shall fail to file the return and to pay the tax on or before the first day of the month following the due date and in addition to the penalty, interest as provided by law shall thereafter accrue and be due and payable. (d) Use of funds. An amount equal to the amount by which the total taxes collected under this article exceed three (3) percent shall be used for the purposes specified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3) and as required therein such funds shall be expended only through a contract or contracts with the state, a department of state government, a state authority, a convention and visitors bureau authority created by a local act of the general assembly for the city, or a private sector nonprofit organization selected by the city or through a contract or contracts with some combination of such entities or organizations. Any such private sector nonprofit organization shall be an organization as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(8)(A). (e) Budget required. Prior to the imposition of the additional excise tax imposed pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. 30-5-301 as amended, and prior to each fiscal year thereafter in which this tax is imposed, the city shall adopt a budget plan specifying how the expenditure requirements of this section will be met and prior to the adoption of such budget plan, the city shall receive from the entity with which it proposes to contract to meet the expenditure requirements of this section, a budget for expenditures to be made by such organization and such budget shall be made a part of the municipal budget plan as required by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(9)(A). (f) Report required. As contemplated by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-56, the city, as a condition of continuing authorization to impose the tax authorized by this section, shall annually file with the state department of community affairs a report specifying the rate of taxation and the amounts collected and expended pursuant to O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 13, art. III. (Ord. of 1-21-91) Secs. 19-8—19-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX ON ENERGY USED IN MANUFACTURING
Sec. 19-20. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "West Point Energy Excise Tax Ordinance." (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-21. - Findings and intent. Georgia law authorizes municipalities to impose an excise tax on the sale or use of energy. The City of West Point has accomplished the imposition of such excise tax through intergovernmental agreement with Troup County, Georgia, as to those portions of West Point which are within Troup County. The purpose of this article is to apply the authorized excise tax on the sale or use of energy within those portions of the corporate limits of the City of West Point, as may be modified from time to time, which are within Harris County, Georgia. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-22. - Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] Dealer shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. Energy shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. Local sales and use tax shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. Purchaser shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-23. - Energy excise tax imposed. (a) In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 13, Article 6, there is imposed within the territorial limits of West Point which are in Harris County, Georgia, an excise tax on the sale or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 8, Article 1 but for the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (b) The sales or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 8, Article 1 but for the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2 includes, but is not limited to, the items listed in subsection (e) of the same Code section. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-24. - Energy excise tax rate and phase-in. (a) The rate of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be phased in over a four (4) year period as directed by O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112(a)(3) and 48-13-112(b) and as set forth below: (1) For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to twenty-five (25) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (2) For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to fifty (50) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (3) For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to seventy-five (75) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and (4) On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to one hundred (100) percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (b) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2(c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in subsections (a)(1), (2) and (3) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in subsection (a)(4) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016, limitation in that subsection. (c) Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the city shall be directed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the special district, but in no event more than two (2) percent. (d) In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district decreases from two (2) percent to one (1) percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. (e) In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district increases from one (1) percent to two (2) percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-25. - Energy excise tax imposition, remittance and recovery. (a) The excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be imposed at the time and be recoverable as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c), (b) The excise tax shall be a debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (c) The dealer collecting the excise tax shall remit the excise tax to the city if the city is the governing authority imposing the excise tax as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (d) Every dealer subject to an excise tax under this article shall be liable for the excise tax at an applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of the excise taxes collected from the purchasers, whichever is greater as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-26. - Exemption certificates. (a) The governing authority of the city, or the collecting officer appointed under this article, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the city and to ascertain whether such purchasers have completed a uniform exemption certificate provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser under the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § [48-8-3.2]. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this article. (b) An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue. The energy provider shall not be liable for failing to collect and remit the excise tax imposed under this article if a purchaser has failed to submit the uniform exemption certificate provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue to such energy provider. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-27. - Commencement of collections and due date. (a) The excise tax imposed pursuant to this article shall become effective on January 1, 2013. (b) The excise tax levied pursuant to this article shall be imposed only at the time that sales and use tax on the sale and use of such energy would have been due and payable under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30 but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (c) The excise tax shall be due and payable in the same manner as would otherwise be required under O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 8, Article 1. (d) All sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month shall be due and payable to the City of West Point monthly on or before the 20th day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-28. - Expenditure of proceeds. The proceeds of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall not be subject to any use or expenditure requirements provided for under any of the local sales and use taxes but shall be authorized to be expended in the same manner as otherwise would have been required under such local sales and use taxes or may be expended for any lawful purpose as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). Any proceeds received by the city pursuant to this article shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-29. - Termination of municipal excise tax. (a) If the city has levied and collected an excise tax within the corporate limits of municipality under this article because the county in which the city is located has refused or failed to enter into an intergovernmental agreement with each municipality wishing to participate in such excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(a)(1) and then the county determines to commence proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2), then the excise tax levied and collected by the municipality shall cease to the extent as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2). (b) If the county has commenced proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2) and the excise tax levied and collected by the municipality has terminated and the municipality has chosen to participate in the county excise tax, then this article shall remain effective for the purposes of O.C.G.A. Title 48, Chapter 13, Article 6 and particularly for the rates required by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12) Sec. 19-30. - Administrative provisions and audit. (a) The city governing authority shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer for collection and administration of the excise tax under this article. (b) The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this article, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. (c) The collecting officer, or designee, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of and locations within the city of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax to the energy dealer under this article. (d) As part by the audit report required by O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7, the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this article. (Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 11-12-12)

div.head: Chapter 20 - TRAFFIC[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Municipal court, Ch. 10; offenses, Ch. 12; signs, Ch. 14; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 17; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4); Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 20-1. - Adoption of rules of road by reference. Pursuant to Chapter 6 of Title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, code sections of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited herein. Sec. 20-2. - Penalty. Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-14. Sec. 20-3. - Official traffic signs and signals; designation, placement and maintenance. (a) The mayor and chairman of the public safety committee shall determine and designate the placing and character of all official traffic signs and signals. All such signs and signals shall be uniform throughout the city, so far as is practicable; provided that all official traffic signs and signals now erected and in operation are hereby designated official traffic signs and signals. (b) Subject to the selection required by subsection (a) above, the chief of police is hereby authorized, and as to those signs and signals required hereunder it shall be his duty, to place and maintain, or cause to be placed and maintained, all official traffic signs and signals. (Code 1967, § 23-1) Sec. 20-4. - Signs, signals, etc., to be obeyed. All vehicular traffic in the city shall observe traffic signs, signals and traffic directions, whether same appear in the form of printed signs or lines and arrows painted on the surface of the streets or sidewalks. (Code 1967, § 23-2) Sec. 20-5. - Skaters or bicycle riders holding to vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person, while riding a bicycle or while skating, to catch on, or hold to, any moving automobile, or other vehicle, within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1967, § 23-5) Bicycles and play vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-290 et seq. Sec. 20-6. - Use of bicycles, roller skates and skateboards. (a) Every person riding a bicycle upon any public street or highway within the city shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the motor vehicle law, except those which by their nature have no application. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle on any of the sidewalks of the city. (c) Every bicycle, when in use after dark, shall be equipped with a white-light lamp visible at least five hundred (500) feet in front of the bicycle and with a red reflector on the rear of the bicycle. (d) No person upon roller skates, a skateboard, coaster, toy vehicle, or any similar device shall be permitted to go upon any public street or highway in the city except while crossing a street at a crosswalk, and, when so crossing, such person shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to pedestrians. (e) No person shall ride roller skates, a skateboard, or other device as described in this section or as may be inferred upon the sidewalks within the fire limits of the city. Sec. 20-7. - Parking of vehicles carrying material extending over rear end. All vehicles carrying ladders, lumber, pipe or any material extending six (6) feet or more over rear end of the body of the vehicle shall not park within the fire limits of the city. (Code 1967, § 23-59) Sec. 20-8. - Parking in residential areas. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle having six (6) or greater wheels to park on public property, including public streets and street rights-of-way, in any residential zone of the city. This section shall not be applicable to any vehicle parked in a residential neighborhood for the purpose of pickup, delivery, loading or unloading. (Ord. of 6-10-91) Sec. 20-9. - Restrictions. Parking shall be restricted at certain times, where; (a) No person shall park any vehicle between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. of Monday through Saturday of any week on or upon those portions of the streets and alleys of the city designated in subsection (b) hereof except a patron as such terms are defined in subsection (c) hereof. (b) Designated areas: Third Avenue on both sides thereof from West 7th Street to West 8th Street; West 8th Street on both sides thereof from 3rd Avenue to 4th Avenue; 4th Avenue on both sides thereof from West 8th Street to the city limits. (c) For purposes of this section "patron" shall mean an individual who is a customer, patron or client of a business, service, enterprise or profession which is located within a building which is adjacent to any of the streets or alleys designated in subsection (b) hereof and is then engaged in the act of being a customer, patron or client of such business, service, enterprise or profession or in the act of transiting between such vehicle and the location of any such business, service, enterprise or procession. (d) Upon conviction of violation of this section or the entry of either a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere to a violation of this section, a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each such violation shall be imposed in addition to any and all other penalties, fines and punishments as shall be imposed in connection with any and all other violations. (e) The restrictions, limitations and prohibitions contained herein are in addition to all other restrictions, limitations and prohibitions that shall exist from time to time relative to parking of vehicle upon the street and alleys designated in subsection (b) hereof. (Ord. of 4-1-01; Ord. No. 13-13, § 1, 12-19-13) Sec. 20-10. - Illegal parking. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to violate the following conditions in reference to the use, occupation of any vehicle on the roadways or right of ways of any city street or state highway within the City of West Point: (1) To remain motionless for any period of time, that causes or may cause a delay in the normal flow of traffic; (2) To park or remain on a sidewalk that is intended for the use of pedestrian traffic; (3) To park in the direction of oncoming traffic; (4) To park in any parking area that has been clearly marked by sign or paint as being designated as a no parking or restricted parking zone; (5) To park in any parking area designated for handicap parking without a valid state issued permit. (Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) Sec. 20-11. - How vehicles to be parked; powers of department of transportation and local authorities. (a) Except as otherwise provided in this Code section, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway shall be stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels parallel to and within twelve (12) inches of the right-hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder. (b) Except when otherwise provided by local ordinance, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of authorized traffic movement, with its right-hand wheels within twelve (12) inches of the right-hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder or with its left-hand wheels within twelve (12) inches of the left-hand curb or as close as practicable to the left edge of the left-hand shoulder. (c) Local authorities may by ordinance permit angle parking on any roadway, except that angle parking shall not be permitted on any federal-aid or state highway unless the department of transportation has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. (d) The department, with respect to highways under its jurisdiction, may place signs prohibiting, restricting, or limiting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles on any highway where, in its opinion, as evidenced by resolution or order entered in its minutes, such stopping, standing, or parking is dangerous to those using the highway or where the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles would unduly interfere with the free movement of traffic thereon. Such signs shall be official signs, and no person shall stop, stand, or park any vehicle in violation of the restrictions on such signs. (Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) Sec. 20-12. - Stopping, standing, or parking outside of business or residential districts. Outside of a business or residential district, no person shall stop, park, or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the roadway when it is practicable to stop, park, or so leave such vehicle off the roadway; but in every event, an unobstructed width of the highway opposite a standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles, and a clear view of the stopped vehicle shall be available from a distance of two hundred (200) feet in each direction upon the highway. (Ord. No. 2012-3, Exh. A, 4-9-12) Secs. 20-13—20-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OPERATION
Sec. 20-31. - Truck routes designated. The public safety committee shall be authorized to determine which streets shall be designated as truck routes through the city. Upon the determination by the public safety committee of which streets shall be truck routes, the committee shall cause suitable signs to be erected indicating the truck routes, and shall cause to be erected signs warning all trucks to remain on the marked truck routes through the city. (Code 1967, § 23-32) Sec. 20-32. - Load limit for trucks using streets; exceptions. (a) It shall be unlawful for any truck having load capacity greater than twelve thousand (12,000) pounds to travel any street within the city, unless such street shall have been previously designated as a truck route. (b) It shall be unlawful for any truck, or other motor vehicle, to travel on any street within the city when such truck or other motor vehicle shall be loaded with a useful load exceeding twelve thousand (12,000) pounds in weight, provided, however, that this section shall not apply or be of any effect as to those streets within the city which have previously been designated as federal or state highways. (Code 1967, § 23-33) Sec. 20-33. - Temporary traffic rules. In cases where the traffic upon the streets of the city may become congested, and upon occasions of parades, at theaters and other public assemblages, where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the police may make temporary rules regulating the traffic in such congested districts, and any person who, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulations by a police officer of the city, shall refuse to comply with such regulations shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 of this Code. (Code 1967, § 23-35) Sec. 20-34. - Police officers to be obeyed. Operators of vehicles shall obey all visual, verbal or written instructions of police officers given in the line and scope of their duty as police officers. (Code 1967, § 23-36) State Law reference— Obedience to authorized persons directing traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. Sec. 20-35. - Yield intersections. (a) The driver of a vehicle approaching a posted yield right-of-way sign shall slow to a speed of not more than ten (10) miles per hour and shall yield right-of-way to all vehicles approaching from the right or left on the intersection roads or streets which are so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. If a driver is involved in a collision at an intersection or interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a yield right-of-way sign, such collision or interference shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the driver's failure to yield right-of-way. (b) Yield right-of-way signs shall be erected at such intersections and in such places as may be authorized and directed by the public safety committee. (Code 1967, § 23-37) Sec. 20-36. - Right-of-way for emergency vehicles. Ambulances, fire trucks and police cars shall have the right-of-way over all vehicles of private individuals, and it shall be a violation of this section if any vehicle shall fail to give the above listed vehicles the right-of-way and pull over to the right side of the street when any such vehicle approaches with siren sounding or the red light on the front burning. (Code 1967, § 23-38) State Law reference— Authorized emergency vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-6. Sec. 20-37. - Driving through processions. Processions shall not be broken through by other vehicles, except by permission of police or traffic officers. (Code 1967, § 23-40) State Law reference— Preventing or disrupting lawful procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34; funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-76. Sec. 20-38. - Driving upon streets being repaired. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any car, motorcycle, bicycle, scooter or conveyance of any kind upon any street in the city that is being repaired. Such streets should be well marked and blocked off. If for any reason any such street is not marked and blocked off, it shall be unlawful to operate any conveyance upon such street if it is obvious that such street is under repair. (Code 1967, § 23-41) Sec. 20-39. - Right-of-way at intersections. When the driver of any vehicle is approaching any street intersection in the city where no traffic-control is present, or where the existing traffic control device is inoperative, he shall give vehicles approaching that intersection on his right the right-of-way, and he shall, if necessary, slow up or stop in order to allow vehicles approaching on his right to pass before he proceeds. (Code 1967, § 23-44) State Law reference— Vehicles approaching or entering intersection, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-70. Sec. 20-40. - Left turn lanes. Left turns shall not be permitted from lanes having arrows indicating right turns or straight ahead traffic. No straight ahead traffic shall be allowed from lanes marked with arrows indicating left turns only.
